[[File:Amadeus_III_of_Geneva.png|thumb|Seal of Amadeus III]] '''Amadeus III''' (29 March 1311<ref>Amadeus' date of birth is indicated in an inscription appearing in the book of hours of his mother, Agnes of Savoy : {{cite journal |last1=Gagnebin |first1=Bernard |title=Le livre d'heures d'Agnès de Savoie, comtesse de Genève |journal=Genava : revue d'histoire de l'art et d'archéologie |date=1963 |volume=11 |page=318-319 |doi=10.5169/seals-727980 |language=fr}}</ref> – 18 January 1367) was the [[Count of Geneva]] from 1320 until his death. He ruled the [[Genevois (province)|Genevois]], but not the city of [[Geneva]] proper, and it was during his time that the term "Genevois" came to be used as it is today. He was the eldest son and successor of [[William III of Geneva|William III]] and Agnes, daughter of [[Amadeus V of Savoy]]. He played a major rôle in the politics of the [[House of Savoy]], serving consecutively as regent and president of the council, and also sitting on the [[Feudalism|feudal]] tribunal—one of three tribunals of the ''Audiences générales''—of the [[Duchy of Aosta]].
==Conflict with Savoy== After the city and castle of [[Annecy]] were devastated in a fire in 1320, Amadeus moved his court to [[La Roche-sur-Foron|La Roche]], which had been the seat of the counts of Geneva between 1124 and 1219. In 1325 Amadeus joined the coalition formed by [[Guigues VIII of Viennois]] against [[Edward of Savoy]]. On 7 August he fought in the victory of the [[Battle of Varey]] over the Savoyards.<ref name=cox37>Eugene L. Cox (1967), ''The Green Count of Savoy: Amadeus VI and Transalpine Savoy in the Fourteenth Century'' (Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press), 37–38.</ref> In 1326 the envoys of [[Charles IV of France]] negotiated a truce so that both counts, of Geneva and of Savoy, could join the king's expedition against [[County of Flanders|Flanders]] in 1327–28. In January 1329 the new [[Aimone, Count of Savoy|Count Aymon of Savoy]] came to terms with Amadeus, and the two established a commission to investigate the disputed territory between the [[Duingt]] and the [[Faverges]]. Ultimately Amadeus became a vassal of Aymon for at least a part of his territories. In 1338 another commission was established to deal with further boundary issues. The relationship between the peaceable and unambitious counts of Geneva and Savoy were, after 1337, always friendly.<ref name=cox37/>
In 1336 Amadeus donated the village of [[Vésenaz]] to the monastery of [[Collonge-Bellerive|Bellerive]].
[[File:Chateaunuit.JPG|thumb|left|The Castle of Chambéry, showing the Sainte-Chapelle where Amadeus III stood godfather at his cousin's baptism, and where later he lived during his regency of the county of Savoy.]]
==Regency of Savoy== On 11 January 1334 Amadeus stood godfather to his first cousin [[Amadeus VI of Savoy]] in the Sainte-Chapelle, then under construction, at [[Chambéry]].<ref>Cox, 13.</ref> He and [[Louis II of Vaud]] were designated by Aymon as regents for the young Amadeus, which roles they assumed on Aymon's death on 22 June 1343. On 26 June, after Aymon's funeral, the young Amadeus was crowned as Count of Savoy and Amadeus of Geneva was the first to swear the oath of fealty. The count of Geneva and the lord of Vaud moved into the [[:fr:Château des ducs de Savoie|Castle of Chambéry]] and signed a written agreement, still preserved, whereby neither could act without the consent of the other, and all acts were to be committed to writing for purposes of review.<ref>Cf. Cox, 34–36, for the details of the regency council laid down in Aymon's will.</ref> In the details of this agreement considerable mutual suspicion can be detected. The lord of Vaud was the senior statesman of the House of Savoy, while Amadeus III was the head of its chief rival.
The first concern of the regents of Savoy after 1343 was securing the succession against the claims of Joan, daughter of Edward of Savoy, who died on 29 June 1344, but not before ceding her claims to [[Philip of Valois, Duke of Orléans|Philip, Duke of Orléans]]. Amadeus and Louis sent an embassy to [[Pope Clement VI]], seeking his support against Joan and Philip. In 1345 Philip signed a treaty relinquishing his claims in return for an annual stipend of 5,000 ''[[livres tournois]]''. The treaty was finalised at Paris and ratified at Chambéry on 25 February 1346.<ref>Cox, 55–56. The royal treasury records Philip's receipt of the first payment on 19 November.</ref>
==President of the council of Savoy== In 1347–48 Amadeus spent a long stay at the [[Avignon Papacy|Avignonese ''curia'']] of Clement VI, who was then concerned with settling disputes in the [[Piedmont]] and [[Lombardy]].<ref>Cox, 68.</ref> On 4 January 1348 the count of Savoy came of age and the regency ended, although it continued in practice, as Amadeus VI was only fourteen years old. Later that year the lord of Vaud died and Amadeus III was left as sole regent, overseeing the "council of Savoy" or "count's council", as the former regency council was then known.<ref name=cox76>Cox, 76–77.</ref> The Savoyard historians [[Jehan Servion]] and [[Jean Cabaret d'Oronville]] record that the council elected one of its members, [[Guillaume de la Baume]], to co-rule with the count of Geneva, who was still not trusted by the Savoyards. Guillaume's election may have been due to French influence.<ref name=cox76/>
In 1348, [[Alamand de Saint-Jeoire]], the [[Bishop of Geneva]], placed two of his castles under the protection of the [[Charles V of France|Dauphin Charles]], future king of France, in an effort to stem the influence of the counts both of Geneva and of Savoy. Amadeus III's officials took reprisals against the diocese, bringing down the condemnation of Clement VI, who nonetheless maintained his good relations with the counts. Amadeus was not deterred. He seized the two castles and removed the Dauphin's banners, replacing them with his own.<ref name=cox76/> On 8 October 1349 an alliance was sealed at [[Cirié]] between Amadeus III of Geneva, Amadeus VI of Savoy, [[Galeazzo II Visconti|Galeazzo II of Milan]], and [[James of Piedmont]]. This alliance was sealed by the marriage of the count of Savoy's sister [[Bianca of Savoy|Bianca]] to Galeazzo on 28 September 1350, which was followed by the creation of the [[Order of the Black Swan]], of which Amadeus of Geneva was named one of the three ''grans seignours'' (along with the count of Savoy and Galeazzo).<ref>Cox, 78–79.</ref>
By 9 July 1351, Amadeus had fallen out with the rest of the council of Savoy and its anti-French policy. On that day, presiding over a meeting of the council at [[Saint-Genix]], he ordered that his opposition to hearing some ambassadors from [[Edward III of England]] be recorded.<ref>Cox, 80. Edward III was then at war with France, the so-called [[Edwardian War]].</ref> Amadeus and the Savoyard chancellor, Georges de Solerio, were largely responsible for the subsequent treaty signed with France on 27 October at [[Avignon]].
In 1351 the peasantry of the [[Valais]] rebelled against the lordship of the [[Bishop of Sion]], then [[Guichard Tavel]], of Genevan family and Savoyard allegiance.<ref>For the causes and background of the rebellion, cf. Cox, 88–91.</ref> On 7 January 1352 the rebels were excommunicated by Clement VI. In March an army, led by Amadeus of Savoy, Amadeus of Geneva, [[John II, Marquess of Montferrat|John II of Montferrat]], and [[Peter IV of Gruyère]] was gathering at [[Saint-Maurice, Switzerland|Saint-Maurice]] to crush the rebels. The inhabitants of the Valais were so intimidated, however, that they surrendered without a fight.<ref>Cox, 91–92.</ref>
==Disputes with Savoy== In May 1352 Amadeus VI of Savoy nullified the treaty of Avignon negotiated by Amadeus III, maligning (probably without basis) the count of Geneva's integrity. In July Amadeus formally withdrew from the council of Savoy and challenged the lords of [[La Baume]], whom he considered his archenemies at the Savoyard court, to war.<ref>Cox, 94.</ref> In 1355, after the conclusion of a war between the count of Savoy and the Dauphin Charles, Amadeus III refused to do homage to his cousin for those fiefs he held of the Dauphin. Amadeus also interfered with the count of Savoy's attempts to militarily occupy the barony of [[Faucigny]] that year, although he did not actively intervene.<ref>Cox, 107–08.</ref> Despite his attempts he was unable to induce [[John II of France]] to intervene in the Faucignerans' favour.<ref>Cox, 112.</ref> On 20 July in the [[Franciscan]] monastery at Geneva, Amadeus III did homage to his former ward the count of Savoy.<ref>Cox, 114.</ref> The issues in dispute had by this time been brought before the [[Emperor Charles IV]], the overlord of the entire region. On 21 August he ordered the count of Savoy not to interfere in the Faucigny or the County of Geneva and put both under his direct protection pending an investigation.<ref>Cox, 121.</ref>
[[File:Annecy-1a.jpg|thumb|The Palais de l'Isle in Annecy, once the seat of the count of Geneva, was a mint under Amadeus III.]]
In May 1358 the Emperor exempted Amadeus III of the jurisdiction of Savoy and granted him the right to appeal to the Emperor all decisions by any other court, whether French or Savoyard. Amadeus, but not his successors, was granted the right to coin money (at the [[Palais de l'Isle]]), legitimise bastards, and create notaries.<ref name=cox129>Cox, 129–31.</ref> The bishop of Geneva immediately opposed the count's right of coinage to the pope. Amadeus of Savoy ordered Amadeus III to renew his oath of homage, but the latter instead asked for the arbitration of [[Jean de Bertrand]], the [[Archbishop of Tarentaise]].<ref name=cox129/> On 2 August the archbishop ruled that Amadeus had the right to mint coins, but not to refuse to renew the oath of homage nor to appeal outside of the courts of the count of Savoy. The count of Geneva refused to accept the result, accusing the archbishop of an "unjust and iniquitous" verdict and vowing to appeal to the Emperor personally (''[[Word of mouth|viva voce]]'').<ref name=cox129/> The two counts came to terms by 21 December. Amadeus III agreed to render homage at Geneva for his fiefs Duingt, Annecy, La Roche, [[Clermont en Genevois|Clermont]], [[Thônes]], [[Gruffy]], [[Arlod]], [[Châtel-Saint-Denis|Châtel]], [[La Bâtie]], and [[Gaillard]], and for the [[Subinfeudation|"sub-fiefs"]] of his own vassals Thomas de Menthon, Guillaume de Compey, and Aymon de Pontverre.<ref name=cox129/> In return Amadeus VI declared the archiepiscopal decision void.
==Order of the Collar and the crusade== In January 1364 Amadeus III was named the second knight of the newly founded [[Order of the Collar]].<ref>The date comes from Cox, 180–81, who cites Jean Servion as the only source for the original membership of the order.</ref> While the formation of the Order was connected with the launch of [[:File:Military campaign of Amadeus VI against Bulgaria (1366-67).png|Amadeus VI's crusade]], Amadeus III did not accompany the crusaders. He sent his eldest son, [[Aymon III of Geneva|Aymon III]], in his place, and he himself died only months after the crusaders departed, which suggests that he was in poor health at the time.<ref>Cox, 184 and 207–08.</ref>
==Family== In 1334 Amadeus married Mathilde or Mahaut d'Auvergne, also called "de Boulogne", with whom he had numerous offspring, four of whom were counts of Geneva in succession: *[[Aymon III of Geneva|Aymon III]], successor as Count of Geneva *[[Amadeus IV of Geneva|Amadeus IV]], succeeded his brother as Count of Geneva *[[John of Geneva|John]], succeeded his brother as Count of Geneva *[[Peter of Geneva|Peter]], succeeded his brother as Count of Geneva *Robert, later the [[Antipope Clement VII]], succeeded his brother as Count of Geneva *Mary, who married first (1361) [[Jean II de Chalon-Arlay]] (died 1362), then (1366) [[Humbert VII de Thoire]], who thus inherited the county of Geneva after the death of Robert *Joan (died 1389), married (1358) [[Raymond V of Baux]], [[Prince of Orange]] *Blanche (died 1420), lady of [[Frontenay]], married (1363) [[Hugh II of Chalon-Arlay]] *Catherine (died 1407), married (1380) [[Amadeo, Prince of Achaea]] *Yolanda, married [[Aimery VI of Narbonne]] *Agnes, became a nun *Louise, married Guillaume III le Sage, lord of Saint-Georges

'''Anti-individualism''' (also known as '''content externalism''') is an approach to various areas of [[thought]] (both [[Analytic philosophy|analytic]] and [[Continental philosophy|continental]]) including [[philosophy]],<ref name=Mckinsey>{{cite journal|last1=Mckinsey|first1=Michael|title=Anti-Individualism and Privileged Access|journal=Analysis|date=January 1991|volume=51|issue=1|pages=9–16|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/3328625?sid=21105511464123&uid=4&uid=3737536&uid=2|accessdate=26 December 2014|doi=10.1093/analys/51.1.9}}</ref> the [[philosophy of psychology]],<ref name=Macdonald>{{cite book|last1=Macdonald|first1=Cynthia|last2=Macdonald|first2=Graham|title=Philosophy of Psychology: Debates on Psychological Explanation|date=February 1995|publisher=Blackwell|isbn=978-0631185413|edition=1st|url=http://philpapers.org/rec/MACPOP|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref> [[French historical studies]],<ref name=Koos>{{cite journal|last1=Koos|first1=Cheryl A.|title=Gender, Anti-Individualism, and Nationalism: The Alliance Nationale and the Pronatalist Backlash against the Femme Moderne, 1933–1940.|journal=French Historical Studies|date=1996|volume=19|issue=3|pages=699–723|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/286641?sid=21105511464123&uid=4&uid=2&uid=3737536|accessdate=26 December 2014|doi=10.2307/286641}}</ref> [[literature]],<ref name=Peppy>{{cite book|last1=Peppis|first1=Paul|title=Literature, Politics, and the English Avant-Garde: Nation and Empire, 1901–1918|date=17 September 2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0521119849|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=csg-34kHuSoC&oi=fnd&pg=PR8&dq=%22anti+individualism%22&ots=yXXK9TNpe9&sig=aCwRvCfUkn0Plf4ryzYpS8hxW9U#v=onepage&q=%22anti%20individualism%22&f=false|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref> [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]]<ref name=burge>{{cite journal|last1=Burge|first1=Tyler|title=Social Anti-Individualism, Objective Reference|journal=Philosophy and Phenomenological Research|date=November 2003|volume=67|issue=3|pages=682–690|doi=10.1111/j.1933-1592.2003.tb00316.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1933-1592.2003.tb00316.x/abstract|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref> and [[linguistics]].
The proponents arguing for anti-individualism in these areas have in common the view that what seems to be internal to the individual is to some degree dependent on the [[social environment]], thus self-knowledge, intentions, [[reason]]ing and [[Value theory|moral value]] may variously be seen as being determined by factors outside the person.<ref>Brown, Jessica: 2004, ''Anti-Individualism and Knowledge''. MIT Press.</ref> The position has been supported by Sanford Goldberg<ref>Goldberg, Sanford (2007). ''Anti-individualism: mind and language, knowledge and justification''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.</ref> and by other thinkers such as [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]], [[Hilary Putnam]] and [[Tyler Burge]].<ref name=burge/>
== Overview == Academic discussion negotiating anti-individualism as a reasonable stance started with [[Tyler Burge]]'s 1988 ''Individuation and Self-Knowledge''<ref name=Burge2>{{cite journal|last1=Burge|first1=Tyler|title=Individuation and Self-Knowledge|journal=The Journal of Philosophy|date=November 1988|volume=85|issue=11|pages=649–663|url=http://isites.harvard.edu/fs/docs/icb.topic1007312.files/Week%2013/burge%20individualism.pdf|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref> being particularly influential. In it, Burge set out to argue for a limited agreement with the Cartesian model of self-cognition as being Authoritative, but also pointed out that knowledge of self-cognition was not always absolute, allowing for the individuation of thought to originate from both the external content of our environment as well as from the internal landscape of our self-knowledge as it is still being discovered: "One can know what one's mental events are and yet not know relevant general facts about the conditions for individuating those events. It is simply not true that the cogito gives us knowledge of the individuation conditions of our thoughts which enables us to "shut off" their individuation conditions from the physical environment".<ref name=Burge2/>
Michael McKinsey builds on this in 1991 discussing Burge's view in his paper ''Anti-Individualism and Privileged Access''<ref name=Mckinsey/> arguing that there is no [[Theory of justification|warrant]] to an [[Epistemology|epistemic]] narrow state of mind (i.e. privileged access) and that there is only a wide state of mind as influenced by the conditions of individuation of thought. Anthony Brueckner then questions McKinsey's take on Burge and McKinsey replies in his ''Accepting the Consequences of Anti-individualism''.<ref name=McKinsey2>{{cite journal|last1=McKinsey|first1=Michael|title=Accepting the Consequences of Anti-individualism|journal=Analysis|date=April 1994|volume=54|issue=2|pages=124–128|url=https://www.academia.edu/8199013/Accepting_the_Consequences_of_Anti-Indiividualism|accessdate=26 December 2014|doi=10.2307/3328832 }}</ref>
Many of the essays found in Hilary Putnam's ''The Twin Earth Chronicles'' are considered early formative works for the anti-individualist model from the analytic perspective.<ref name=Putnam>{{cite book|last1=Hilary|first1=Putnam|title=The Twin Earth Chronicles: Twenty Years of Reflection on Hilary Putnam's "The Meaning of 'Meaning'"|date=1 July 1996|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=978-1563248740|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q2W0y3NF3OwC&pg=PA355&lpg=PA355&dq=Michael+McKinsey+anti-individualism+Tyler_Burge&source=bl&ots=4U0DJwLE5F&sig=qjkbv3L83aafUsws46qZicsPZfI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hECdVODvBZDz8gXK44CABg&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref>

[[Image:Map Guj Nat Parks Sanctuary.png|thumb|right|The [[Gir Forest]] in the State of [[Gujarat]], [[India]] is the last natural habitat of more than 523 wild Asiatic lions, though plans are afoot to re-introduce some to Palpur-[[Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary]] in the neighboring State of [[Madhya Pradesh]] in n India to ensure their longterm survival against epidemics and natural calamities.]]
The '''Asiatic Lion Reintroduction Project''' is an initiative of the [[India]]n Government to provide safeguards to the [[Asiatic lion]] (''[[Panthera leo leo]]''){{efn|In 2017, due to the Asiatic lion's close relationship with the [[Barbary lion]], the Cat Classification Taskforce of the Cat Specialist Group subsumed ''P. l. persica'' to ''P. l. leo''.<ref name="Catsg2017">{{cite journal |author1=Kitchener, A. C. |author2=Breitenmoser-Würsten, C. |author3=Eizirik, E. |author4=Gentry, A. |author5=Werdelin, L. |author6=Wilting, A. |author7=Yamaguchi, N. |author8=Abramov, A. V. |author9=Christiansen, P. |author10=Driscoll, C. |author11=Duckworth, J. W. |author12=Johnson, W. |author13=Luo, S.-J. |author14=Meijaard, E. |author15=O’Donoghue, P. |author16=Sanderson, J. |author17=Seymour, K. |author18=Bruford, M. |author19=Groves, C. |author20=Hoffmann, M. |author21=Nowell, K. |author22=Timmons, Z. |author23=Tobe, S. |year=2017 |title=A revised taxonomy of the Felidae: The final report of the Cat Classification Task Force of the IUCN Cat Specialist Group |journal=Cat News |issue=Special Issue 11 |page=71−73 |url=https://repository.si.edu/bitstream/handle/10088/32616/A_revised_Felidae_Taxonomy_CatNews.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y}}</ref>}} from [[extinction]] in the wild by means of reintroduction. The last wild population of the Asiatic lion is found in the [[Kathiawar Peninsula|region]] of [[Gir Forest National Park]], in the state of [[Gujarat]]. The single population faces the threats of [[epidemics]], [[natural disasters]] and other [[Man-made hazards|anthropogenic factors]]. The project aims to establish a second independent population of [[Asiatic lion]]s at the [[Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary]] in the Indian state of [[Madhya Pradesh]].<ref name="Field Days">{{cite book|last=Johnsingh|first=AJT|title=Field Days: A Naturalist's Journey Through South and Southeast Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EU3inCiGFYYC&pg=PA126|accessdate=22 April 2013|date=1 February 2006|publisher=Universities Press|isbn=978-81-7371-552-5|pages=126–138}}</ref> However, the proposed translocation has been bitterly contested by the state government.
==History== [[File:Lion Reintron Sites in India.png|thumbnail|right|Historical and proposed lion reintroduction sites in India]] The distribution of Asiatic lion, once found widely in West and South Asia, dwindled to a single population in the Gir Forest National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary in India.<ref name="Wild Cats of the World">{{cite book|last1=Sunquist|first1=Mel|last2=Sunquist|first2=Fiona|title=Wild Cats of the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hFbJWMh9-OAC&pg=PA304|accessdate=22 April 2013|date=15 August 2002|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-77999-7|page=297}}</ref> The population at Gir declined to 18 animals in 1893 but increased due to protection and conservation efforts to 284 in 1994.<ref name="Pride in Place">{{cite journal|last1=Paulson |first1=Mark |year=1999 |title=Pride in Place: Reintroduction of Asiatic Lions in Gir Forest, India |journal=Restoration and Reclamation Review |volume=4 |issue=3 |pages= |publisher=Dept of Horticultural Science, University of Minnesota |doi= |url=http://conservancy.umn.edu/bitstream/59294/1/4.3.Paulson.pdf |accessdate=19 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120901034324/http://conservancy.umn.edu/bitstream/59294/1/4.3.Paulson.pdf |archivedate=1 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> The Gir Wildlife Sanctuary is now highly overpopulated with lions, the 2015 census showed the strength to be 523 lions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/GUJ-AHD-asiatic-lions-gujarat---s-roar-in-court-lacked-substance-4236798-NOR.html |title=Asiatic lions: Gujarat’s roar in court lacked substance |last1=Shah |first1=Jumana |date=16 April 2013 |work=DailyBhaskar.com |publisher=DB Corp Ltd., Noida, UP, India |accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> There are numerous deaths in the population annually because of ever increasing competition between the human and animal overcrowding. Asiatic lion prides require large [[territory (animal)|territories]] but there is limited space at Gir wildlife sanctuary, which is boxed in on all sides by heavy human habitation.<ref name="Field Days"/> Gir lions have started moving outwards from the sanctuary and establishing homes outside the protected areas. The lions are now spread over {{convert|16000|km2|sqmi}} in the vicinity of 1050 villages in three contiguous districts - [[Amreli]], [[Bhavnagar]] and [[Junagadh]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-07-15/flora-fauna/40588939_1_asiatic-lions-gir-forest-sasan-gir |title=Asiatic lions have homes in over 1,000 Saurashtra villages |author=Parmar, Vijaysinh |date=15 July 2013 |website=ndiatimes.com |accessdate=23 July 2013|publisher=Bennett & Coleman Ltd.}}</ref>
===Sheopur introduction of 1904=== The [[Maharaja of Gwalior]], on being encouraged by [[Lord Curzon]] in 1904, imported cubs of [[African lion]]s and attempted to introduce them in the wild in the forests near Sheopur. The introduced lions took to raiding livestock and some even turned to [[man-eater|man-eating]], subsequent to which they were all eventually tracked down and shot.<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-05-17/ahmedabad/31747947_1_lions-palpur-kuno-three-cubs ''Past efforts to settle lions in Madhya Pradesh had failed''], May 17, 2012, Ahmedabad (Gujarat) Edition, Times of India.</ref>
===The Chandraprabha relocation of 1957=== The concept of reintroduction for purposes of conservation was accepted in 1956 by the Indian Wildlife Board during a meeting of their executive committee at Sasan Gir and the offer by the state government of [[Uttar Pradesh]] to host a second population in the Chakia forests was accepted. In 1956 one lion and two lionesses were captured from Gir, placed in the Sakkarbuagh Zoo in Junagadh for nine months and translocated in 1957 to the {{convert|96|km2|sqmi}} [[Chandra Prabha Sanctuary]], newly established for the reintroduction, near [[Varanasi]] in [[Uttar Pradesh]]. An enclosure was created with a {{convert|3|m|ft}} high barbed wire fence within the sanctuary in which the lions were temporarily housed before being released in the sanctuary. Initially the lions prospered increasing in number to four in 1958, five in 1960, seven in 1962 and eleven in 1965 after which the population died out inexplicably.
Johnsingh (2006) attributes the failure of the translocation to three causes – inadequate area, lack of systematic monitoring using scientific techniques and unrestricted movement of grazing animals throughout the sanctuary possibly leading to conflict with the herders.<ref name="Field Days"/> Small size of area, the long period of captivity in Junagadh zoo, absence of education of the local villagers and lack of conflict resolution mechanism are also listed as contributory factors in Chellam and Johnsingh (1999).<ref name="Chellam & Johnsingh(1999)">{{cite journal|last1=Chellam |first1=Ravi |last2=Johnsingh |first2=A.J.T. |year=1999 |title=Translocating Asiatic Lions, India |journal=Re-introduction News |issue=18 |pages=11–13 |publisher= |issn=1560-3709 |url=http://www.iucn.org/themes/ssc/sgs/rsg/rsgcdrom/PDFs/RNews18.pdf |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20081003120756/http://iucn.org/themes/ssc/sgs/rsg/rsgcdrom/pdfs/rnews18.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 October 2008 |accessdate=19 April 2013 }}</ref>
===The Wildlife Institute of India initiative=== The [[Wildlife Institute of India]] (WII) began studying the Asiatic lion in its habitat in from 1986 onwards and collected fundamental data about the lion, its feeding, use of habitat and ranging habits. Key findings of the study were that the lions largely preyed upon the wild herbivores such as [[sambar deer|sambar]] (''Rusa unicolor'') and [[chital]] (''Axis axis'') and that the size of home range was {{convert|70|km2|sqmi}} for females and {{convert|140|km2|sqmi}} for the males.<ref name="Chellam & Johnsingh(1999)"/> In 1990, the WII proposed the creation of a second wild population of Asiatic lions to safeguard the species against potential calamities in Gujarat's Gir National Park.<ref name="Science Trumps Politics">{{cite web |url=http://tehelka.com/science-trumps-politics/ |title=Science Trumps Politics |last1=Mazoomdar |first1=Jay |last2= |first2= |date=27 April 2013 |work=Tehelka magazine |publisher=Tehelka.com |accessdate=19 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6G4EcRM80?url=http://tehelka.com/science-trumps-politics/ |archivedate=April 22, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==1993 PHVA report== In 1993, a workshop was held on the Population and Habitat Viability Assessment (PHVA) of Asiatic lion and the report was presented to the state forest departments in [[Vadodara]], Gujarat. State forest departments were asked to suggest suitable sites for reintroduction and provide the basic ecological data.<ref name="Chellam & Johnsingh(1999)"/>
During the workshop, a number of teams were formed to focus on varied aspects of the conservation biology of the Asiatic lion such as monitoring, habitat (further subdivided into Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan sub-groups), population modelling, prey-base requirements, lion-human interactions, translocation, captive zoo animals, public education, veterinary, reproductive and genetic aspects etc.<ref name = "PHVA">{{cite web |url=http://www.zooreach.org/downloads/ZOO_CAMP_PHVA_reports/1993_Asiatic_Lion_PHVA_report.pdf |title=Asiatic Lion Report |editor1-last = Ashraf |editor1-first= N.V.K. |editor2-last = Chellam |editor2-first= Ravi |editor3-last = Sharma |editor3-first= D. |editor4-last = Molur |editor4-first= Sanjay |editor5-last = Walker |editor5-first= Sally |date=May 1995 |work=Population & Habitat Viability Assessment P.H.V.A. and Global Animal Survival Plan Workshops (18–21 October 1993, Baroda, India) |publisher=Zoo Outreach Organisation / CBSG, India |accessdate=25 April 2013}}</ref>
The sites were assessed and ranked for suitability as follows:<ref name = "PHVA"/> * [[Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary]] - found most suitable for reintroduction.<ref name="Field Days"/> * [[Sita Mata Wildlife Sanctuary]] - later rejected due to human interference and inadequate prey population.<ref name="Field Days"/> * [[Darrah National Park|Darrah]] - [[Jawahar Sagar Wildlife Sanctuary]] - later rejected due to degraded habitat and unsuitable geography.<ref name="Field Days"/> * [[Kumbhalgarh Wildlife Sanctuary]] - assessed as having limited area, unsuitable terrain, limited water and prey base as well as disturbance.<ref name = "PHVA"/> * [[Barda Wildlife Sanctuary]] - assessed as having scarcity of water, prey and forage, as well as encroachment and disturbance.<ref name = "PHVA"/>
The PHVA report strongly favoured the scientific management of reintroduction of Asiatic lions to another site:<ref name = "PHVA"/> {{quote|The overwhelming consensus of the Workshop was that an alternative habitat for the Asiatic lion must be established with all possible speed, but without compromise of the accepted strategies and principles governing systematic and scientific reintroduction. This should be done simultaneously with strengthening effective protection and management of the Gir Forest and assuring the viability of the captive population and alternative genetic resources.}}
The PHVA deliberations were followed by visits to the three most promising site, viz Kuno, Darrah-Jawaharsagar and Sitamata WLS by a survey team of WII headed by Dr [[Ravi Chellam]]. The team evaluated sites over various parameters and compared the same with respect to Gir Forest for determining the suitability of sites. They presented their findings in 1995 to the Government of India and the state forest departments.<ref name="Chellam & Johnsingh(1999)"/><ref name = "PHVA"/> WII researchers confirmed that the Palpur-Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary was the most promising location to re-establish a free ranging population of the Asiatic lions and in 2007 certified it ready to receive its first batch of translocated lions.<ref name="JSSPGQQ2007">{{cite journal |last1=Johnsingh |first1=A.J.T. |last2=Goyal |first2=S.P. |last3=Qureshi|first3=Qamar|year=2007 |title=Preparations for the reintroduction of Asiatic lion Panthera leo persica into Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary, Madhya Pradesh, India |journal=Oryx |volume= |issue=41 |pages=93–96 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |doi=10.1017/S0030605307001512 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/production/action/cjoGetFulltext?fulltextid=851224 |accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref>
==Project framework== The framework of the Lion Introduction Project emerged from the transformation of a Monitoring Committee, set up by the Government of India, which met on 10 March 2004 for effective implementation of the reintroduction at Kuno.<ref name="Supreme Court Verdict">{{cite web |url=http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgs1.aspx?filename=40278 |title=Supreme Court judgement - Centre for Environment Law, WWF-I Versus Union of India & Others : On the issue of a second home for Asiatic Lion|date=16 April 2013 |website=The Judgement Information System |publisher=Government of India |accessdate=28 April 2013}}</ref>
At the meeting the WII Site Survey was examined and it was understood that Kuno Palpur Sanctuary was the most suitable site for reintroduction. The Committee formulated a three phase framework for the conservation project to last for two decades as follows :<ref name="Supreme Court Verdict"/> * During the first phase, slated from 1995-2000, the 24 villages would be shifted out of the sanctuary and the habitat would be improved. * The second phase would last from 2000 to 2005 and would include fencing off of the lion reintroduction site, the actual trans-location, as well as research and monitoring. * The final phase III would last from 2005 to 2015 and would focus on eco-development of the region.
At that point in time, the project was in Phase II and 18 of the 24 villages had been rehabilitated from Kuno. The refusal of Gujarat state to provide lions was mentioned during this meeting by the Chief Wildlife Warden of Gujarat. A number of steps were approved with consensus which included the engaging of the Gujarat State Government as to the necessity of the project, preparation of a trans-location road map, fresh assessment of prey base of Kuno by WII and continued funding support for welfare measures and habitat improvement for the existing fauna at Kuno.<ref name="Supreme Court Verdict"/>
==Lion reintroduction at Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary== [[Image:Panthera leo persica male.jpg|thumb|left|250px|A male Asiatic lion]] [[Image:Asiatic.lioness.arp.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Asiatic lioness, named MOTI, at Bristol Zoo, England (1996)]]
===Establishing the wildlife sanctuary=== The Madhya Pradesh state forest department notified {{convert|345|sqkm|sqmi}} of the Kuno Palpur area as a Wildlife Sanctuary in 1981.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mpforest.org/kuno.html |title=Kuno Sanctuary |publisher=Madhya Pradesh State Forest Department |accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref> In April 2002, a separate Wildlife Division was established for Kuno, effectively increasing the protected area for wildlife to {{convert|1268.861|sqkm|sqmi}}.<ref name="Supreme Court Verdict"/>
===Rehabilitation of villagers=== Twenty four villages of the [[Sahariya]] tribe, comprising 1545 families, were moved out from the core area and rehabilitated by the state government with assistance from the Central Government. Due to a paucity of suitable revenue lands in the vicinity of Kuno, the state government proposed relocating the villages on degraded protected forests, a move approved by the [[Ministry of Environment and Forests]] (MOEF) of the Government of India, which granted its approval under Section 2 of the [[Forest (Conservation) Act 1980]] for diversion of {{convert|3395.9|ha|acre}}. By 2002-2003, all 24 villages and the identified families were relocated outside Kuno and the former village area converted into grasslands.<ref name="Supreme Court Verdict"/>
<!--The resettled villages were allocated housing and agricultural land and the rehabilitation plan included expenses on infrastructure development, so that they can have access to basic amenities like roads, schools and a hospital.{{fact|date=May 2013}}.-->The Madhya Pradesh state government informed the Supreme Court that each family was given {{convert|2|ha|acre}} of cultivable land, in addition to {{convert|500|m2|sqyd}} for housing along with building constructional material costing Rs 1,00,000/- per house. The net outflow to the Central Government was Rs.15 crores.<ref name="Supreme Court Verdict"/>
Major gaps remain in the implementation of the rehabilitation measures, with villagers alleging that they have got little of the rehabilitation package they were promised.<ref name="Bunsha2005">{{cite journal|author=Bunsha, Dionne |url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/fline/fl2211/stories/20050603002308300.htm |title= Left high and dry |website= Frontline|volume=22|issue=11|date= 21 May 2003 |accessdate= 12 Jun 2013}}</ref><ref name="Arpan">{{cite web|author=Samrakshan Trust |year=2006 |url=http://www.ruffordsmallgrants.org/files/Arpan%20Progress%20Report.pdf |title=The Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary – a new home for Asiatic Lions? |accessdate=12 June 2013 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The negative economic impact of the displacement to villagers from Kuno sanctuary has raised a controversy over the merits of species preservation via dislocation of human populations living inside Protected Areas.<ref name = "Kabra 2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.india-seminar.com/2007/577/577_asmita_kabra.htm |author=Kabra, Asmita |title=Preservation via Dislocation |website=Seminar|date= September 2007|accessdate= 13 June 2013}}</ref> [[NGO]]s, such as the [[Samrakshan Trust]], have been working for better rehabilitation of villagers who agreed to move out of the Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary.<ref name="Samrakshan2">{{cite web |url=http://www.samrakshan.org/lc_kuno.htm |title=The Kuno Initiative |website=Samrakshan Trust |accessdate=13 June 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023042606/http://www.samrakshan.org/lc_kuno.htm |archive-date=2013-10-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Opposition by the Gujarat government== In 2004, the state government refused to part with the first pride of 19 animals planned for relocation. The state considers the lions as "heritage of the state" and the issue of handing over lions has become a political issue.<ref name="Mitra2005">{{cite book|last=Mitra|first=Sudipta|title=Gir Forest and the saga of the Asiatic lion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J0rME6RjC1sC&pg=PA226|accessdate=22 April 2013|year=2005|publisher=Indus Publishing|isbn=978-81-7387-183-2|pages=226–227}}</ref> Mangubhai Patel, then State Forest Minister, went on record to state that:<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2004-09-02/ahmedabad/27162985_1_asiatic-lion-gir-forest-gir-national-park |title=Gir will be lions' only home: Gujarat |author=Times News Network |date=2 September 2004 |work=The [[Times of India]] - City - Ahmedabad |publisher=Bennet & Coleman|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> ::{{quote|''There is no need to shift lions from Gir. We will ensure their survival here.''}}
As early as 2009, the continued opposition of the Gujarat state government led to the Madhya Pradesh Forest Department's exploration of the possibility of procuring zoo-bred Asiatic lions and shifting them and their descendants to Palpur-Kuno.<ref name="DH-6-10-09">{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/29405/zoo-bred-asiatic-lions-mp.html|title=Zoo-bred Asiatic lions for MP jungles?|author=Kaushik, Himanshu|date=6 October 2009 |website=DeccanHerald.com |accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref>
The [[Gujarat]] state government has, over time, made various arguments against translocating lions to Madhya Pradesh (MP), such as that the Kuno sanctuary was not suitable lion habitat and that it had inadequate prey base, that MP had been unable to provide adequate protection to tigers in its [[Panna National Park]] and the lions if reintroduced there would be in danger, that the proposed [[Cheetah reintroduction in India|introduction]] of [[Southern African cheetah]]s to Kuno rendered it unsuitable for lion reintroduction.<ref name="BBCNews">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22154756 |title=Gujarat's Asiatic lions must be shared - Indian court |author= |date=15 April 2013 |work=BBC News Asia |publisher= |accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref>
The Gujarat State Wildlife Department proposed new homes for lions in the [[Barda Wildlife Sanctuary]]<ref name="Barda">{{cite web|url=http://girasiaticlion.blogspot.in/2012/04/lions-roar-to-echo-in-porbandars-barda.html |title=Lions' roar to echo in Porbandar's Barda Sanctuary|website=DNA| author=Jha, Paras K.| author2=Gagdekar, Roxy| last-author-amp=yes |date= 4 April 2012|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref> and [[Bhavnagar Amreli Forest]] instead.<ref name="Jesar">{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2006-03-19/ahmedabad/27789455_1_gir-sanctuary-asiatic-lions-mitiala |title=New sanctuary for lions to come up at Jesar|date=19 March 2006 |author=Pathak, Anil |accessdate=13 June 2013 |work=The Times Of India}}</ref> Gir's lions have spread beyond the protective area and the measures of the state to engage this phenomenon are being portrayed as providing adequate dispersal to the lion population to prevent disease. Gujarat also played an emotional card by declaring before the Supreme Court that the lion was inextricably bound to the culture of Gujarat and that it was a "family member", hence could not be provided for translocation to Kuno.
This stand of Gujarat suffered a setback when on 15 April 2013, the [[Supreme Court of India]] acknowledged translocation to Kuno as being in the best interest of the species and rejected the Gujarat Government's objections, instead ordering the translocation to be carried out within six months. A ''bandh'' was called in the villages adjoining the Sasan Gir region on 18 April 2013 protesting the Supreme Court decision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Gujarat/Sasan-bandh-against-SC-verdict-on-trans-location-of-lions/Article1-1046408.aspx |title=Sasan bandh against SC verdict on trans-location of lions |author=PTI |date=18 April 2013 |work=[[Hindustan Times]] |publisher=HT Media Ltd. |accessdate=23 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421090548/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Gujarat/Sasan-bandh-against-SC-verdict-on-trans-location-of-lions/Article1-1046408.aspx |archivedate=21 April 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Supreme Court verdict and aftermath== In light of the State Government of Gujarat's refusal to permit the reintroduction of Asiatic lions, a writ petition was filed in 1995 by the Centre for Environment Law and WWF-I in the Indian Supreme Court to get the Gujarat State Government to release a few prides of Asiatic lions for the Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary. The Indian Supreme Court fast-tracked the case and delivered a judgement on 16 April 2013 permitting the reintroduction of lions to Kuno, over-ruling the objections of the Gujarat Government.<ref name="Supreme Court Verdict"/>
The Gujarat Government filed on 1 July 2013 for a review in the Supreme Court of its 16 April ruling. In its petition, the Gujarat state government claimed that: ::{{quote|''top carnivores have never been successfully translocated''}} The state has put forward the argument that translocation would break social bonds between members of groups or prides, which are vital for lion survival. The reported presence of tiger cubs in Palpur-Kuno was emphasised, saying that it could result in conflict between these top predators. The state proposed, instead, a second home for lions within Gujarat itself, claiming it would have numerous advantages including being in tune with international guidelines.<ref name="Reluctant">{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-07-02/india/40328037_1_asiatic-lions-kuno-palpur-kuno-wildlife-sanctuary |title=Reluctant to part with lions, Gujarat moves SC |author=Mahapatra, Dhananjay |date=2 July 2013 |work=Times of India |publisher=Bennett & Coleman |accessdate=13 July 2013}}</ref> The continued reluctance of the state to part with lions for translocation has come under criticism from prominent environmentalists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/environmentalists-slam-gujarat-s-fight-over-gir-lions-387050 |title=Environmentalists slam Gujarat's fight over Gir lions |author=Agence France-Presse |date=2 July 2013 |work=NDTV.com |publisher=NDTV Convergence Limited|accessdate=13 July 2013}}</ref>
Post the verdict, fears have been voiced by Gujarati environmentalists over the gun culture of Madhya Pradesh and number of firearms in Sheopur, the region where the Kuno Palpur sanctuary is located and it is suggested that translocation to such an area would be in violation of IUCN norms on the subject.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-29/flora-fauna/38903035_1_asiatic-lion-gir-kuno-palpur |title=Can't send lions to gun country: International Union for Conservation of Nature norms |last1=Kaushik |first1=Himanshu |date=29 April 2013 |website=Times of India |publisher=Bennett & Coleman |accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref> With the release of [[IUCN]] guidelines on translocation, opponents of the project have cited from the provisions and also claimed that the history of translocations especially in India is dismal and hence translocation is not favoured.<ref name="IUCN Guidelines">{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/flora-fauna/Translocating-animals-outside-home-turf-is-high-risk-International-Union-for-Conservation-of-Nature/articleshow/21154628.cms |title=Translocating animals outside home turf is high risk: International Union for Conservation of Nature |author=Kaushik, Himanshu | date=19 July 2013 |website=Indiatimes.com |publisher=Bennett & Coleman Ltd. |accessdate=23 July 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Empower">{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-06-28/ahmedabad/40255333_1_translocation-gir-lions-manas |title=10 translocations have failed worldwide |author=Kaushik, Himanshu | date=28 Jun 2013 |website=Indiatimes.com |publisher=Bennett & Coleman Ltd. |accessdate=23 July 2013 }}</ref> The natural spread of over-populated lions from an original range of over {{convert|1412|km2|sqmi}} to an area extending over {{convert|10500|km2|sqmi}}, is considered to mitigate against the risk of epidemic disease.<ref name="ModiChouhan">{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/narendra-modi-translocation-of-asiatic-lions-asiatic-lion-gir-forests-kuno-palpur-sanctuary/1/305463.html |title=Modi, Chouhan continue sparring over translocation of lions |author=Chaturvedi, Devika | date=4 September 2013 |website=IndiaToday.in |publisher=Living Media India Limited. |accessdate=28 September 2013 }}</ref>
===2014=== The Gujarat's government's curative petition against relocation of the wild Asiatic lions from the Gir Forest to Madhya Pradesh was dismissed by the Supreme Court on 14 August 2014.<ref name="TOI-15-08-14">{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/MP-had-plan-to-shift-zoo-bred-lions-looking-at-Modis-objection-on-those-in-wild/articleshow/40306682.cms|title=MP had plan to shift zoo-bred lions, looking at Modi's objection on those in wild|author=Naveen, P.|date=15 August 2014 |website=Indiatimes.com |accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref>
In the face of continued opposition, the Madhya Pradesh government is considering an alternate plan to release zoo-bred lions from [[Nehru Zoological Park|Hyderabad]] and [[Sakkarbaug Zoological Garden|Sakkarbaug]], a move which has been criticised in the light of the deaths of two newly translocated zoo-bred lions in the [[Etawah Safari Park|safari park at Etawah]], [[Uttar Pradesh]].<ref name="TOI-05-12-14">{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/flora-fauna/No-sign-of-Gir-transfer-MP-seeks-to-shift-zoo-lions-to-Kuno/articleshow/45379624.cms|title=No sign of Gir transfer, MP seeks to shift zoo lions to Kuno|author=Naveen, P.|date=5 December 2014 |website=Indiatimes.com |accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref>
After the dismissal of the Gujarat State petition, two NGOs from Gujarat have filed separate petitions against the translocation order, one on the grounds that certain relevant facts have not been brought to the notice of the apex court, the other stating that the importance of Kuno-Palpur as a corridor for migrating tigers between [[Ranthambore National Park]] in Rajasthan and [[Madhav National Park]] in Madhya Prdesh had been downplayed.<ref name="TOI-15-08-14"/>
===2017=== As of December 2017, Madhya Pradesh still has not received lions from Gujarat. For this reason, it may have given up on trying to acquire them.<ref name="TOI 2017">{{cite news |work=Times of India |title=Tired of Gujarat reluctance on Gir lions, MP to release tigers in Kuno |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/tired-of-gujarat-reluctance-on-gir-lions-mp-to-release-tigers-in-kuno/articleshow/61937836.cms |date=2017-12-05 |accessdate=2018-01-27}}</ref><ref name="HT 2017">{{cite news |work=Hindustan Times |title=Stalemate on translocation of Gir lions Kuno Palpur in Madhya Pradesh to be used as tiger habitat now |url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/bhopal/stalemate-on-translocation-of-gir-lionskuno-palpur-in-madhya-pradesh-to-be-used-as-tiger-habitat-now/story-hX8ELtxSSL4I8GeLTh6xYI.html |date=2017-12-07 |accessdate=2018-01-27}}</ref>
===2018=== As of October 2018, the lions were still in Gujarat, and 23 of them were found dead. 4 of them had died of the infection which killed several [[East African lion]]s in the [[Serengeti]] [[ecoregion]], the [[canine distemper virus]].<ref name="TheTimes 10-2018">{{cite news |last=Ray |first=Saptarshi |title=Rare Asiatic lions threatened as sanctuary deaths rise |publisher=[[The Times]] |location=[[Delhi]] |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/rare-asiatic-lions-threatened-as-sanctuary-deaths-rise-gdcvkls2l |date=2018-10-05 |access-date=2018-05-05}}</ref><ref name="IndiaTimes 10-2018">{{cite news |last=Bobins |first=Abraham |title=Did The Failure To Set Up A 'Second Home' For In Madhya Pradesh Cause Lion Deaths In Gir? |publisher=[[Times Internet|Indiatimes]] |url=https://www.indiatimes.com/news/india/did-the-failure-to-set-up-a-second-home-for-in-madhya-pradesh-cause-lion-deaths-in-gir-354235.html |date=2018-10-05 |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref><ref name="PTI 10-2018">{{cite news |work=[[Press Trust of India]] |title=Asiatic lions in Gujarat’s Gir forest dying of Canine Distemper Virus: ICMR |publisher=The [[Hindustan Times]] |location=[[New Delhi]] |url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/asiatic-lions-in-gujarat-s-gir-forest-dying-of-canine-distemper-virus-icmr/story-vXPHiwUIyM0ksK84EgPDWO.html |date=2018-10-05 |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>
==Translocation plan within Gujarat== The plan is to [[reintroduction of a species|reintroduce]] a pride or two of wild, free-ranging Asiatic lions from [[Gir Forest]] in the neighboring Indian state of [[Gujarat]] to start with.<ref name="Bunsha2">{{cite journal|author=Bunsha, Dionne |url=http://www.flonnet.com/fl2210/stories/20050520000106500.htm |title=A kingdom too small |journal=Frontline |volume=22 |issue=10 |date=20 May 2007 |accessdate=13 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212165913/http://www.flonnet.com/fl2210/stories/20050520000106500.htm |archivedate=12 February 2012 }}</ref>
In compliance with the Supreme Court order of 15 April 2013, the [[Ministry of Environment and Forests]] has constituted a panel for deciding the best course of action in translocation of animals to Gir. The panel comprises 12 members including member secretary [[National Tiger Conservation Authority]], the Chief Wildlife Wardens of Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh, member [[Wildlife Institute of India]], and scientists Drs Ravi Chellam, Y.V. Jhala, NK Ranjeet Singh and PR Sinha. The panel will advice both the states on technical aspect of transloction, decide the composition of animals to be translocated, select the prides and animals, supervise the translocation, monitor it and periodically report to the Ministry.<ref name="GirRoarMP">{{cite news|url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/flora-fauna/Gir-lions-to-roar-in-MP-soon/articleshow/21263193.cms |title=Gir lions to roar in MP soon |author=Naveen, P. |website=timesofindia.com |publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd. | date=23 July 2013 |accessdate=23 July 2013 }}</ref> During the first deliberations on 29 July 2013, the panel acceded the need to follow the recent IUCN translocation guidelines but brushed aside Gujarat's objections against the process. A two-member team comprising Dr Ravi Chellam and Dr Y.V. Jhala has been set up to decide the translocation protocol and report within six weeks.<ref name="TOI-15-08-14"/><ref name="TransPanel">{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Translocation-of-Asiatic-lions-Gujarats-objections-brushed-aside/articleshow/21475800.cms | title=Translocation of Asiatic lions: Gujarat’s objections brushed aside |author= Kaushik, Himanshu |author2= Naveen, P. |last-author-amp= yes| website=timesofindia.com | publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd. | date=30 July 2013 |accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref>
Gujarat objected to meeting of the 12-member panel on 29 July 2013 before its petition had been reviewed and also to the presence of tiger experts on the panel, claiming that lion experts from Gujarat had been ignored, however that petition was rejected by the Supreme Court.<ref name="Object">{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-07-27/flora-fauna/40832735_1_gir-lions-asiatic-lions-gujarat-government|title=Gujarat objects to tiger experts on panel to shift Gir lions|author=Kaushik, Himanshu|date=27 July 2013 |website=Indiatimes.com |publisher=Bennett & Coleman Ltd. |accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref>
In a further development, in April 2015, the Union government has admitted that Madhya Pradesh will have to enlarge the wildlife sanctuary's size, from {{convert|349|km2|sqmi}} to {{convert|700|km2|sqmi}} in order to implement the translocation of the Asiatic lions to Kuno-Palpur from Gujarat's Sasan Gir, a suggestion made in the original project report. This is the first time that the Government of India has accepted that the sanctuary needs to be enlarged. However, the expansion would require the relocation of several big villages, a move the Madhya Pradesh government is not keen to undertake. The Madhya Pradesh Forest Department is of the view that the present sanctuary area and its buffer total over 700 km<sup>2</sup> and are therefore adequate, but have made no mention of notifying the buffer zone area also as a sanctuary.<ref name="TOI-22-04-15">{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Kuno-expansion-must-to-house-lions/articleshow/47007365.cms|title=Kuno expansion must to house lions|author=Himanshu Kaushik|website=Indiatimes.com|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref>
In a reversal of position, the Ministry of Environment and Forests decided in a meeting in June 2015 against translocation at present on the grounds that it would be detrimental to the breeding and survival of the lions as they lived in social prides. The turn-around of stance has been attributed by environmentalists supporting the translocation to [[Narendra Modi]] who had as Chief Minister of Gujarat stated that the lion was the pride of Gujarat and had publicly declared his opposition to the transfer of lions outside the state.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/niSTqjTWnYXmlhogS55tuM/Gir-Lions-Forest-ministry-cites-challenges-in-Madhya-Prades.html |title=Gir lions’ relocation to Madhya Pradesh faces hurdle |website=LiveMint |author=Aggarwal, Mayank |date=18 June 2015 |accessdate=19 Jun 2015}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=October 2018}} A '''biosatellite''' is an [[satellite| artificial satellite]] designed to carry plants or animals in [[outer space]].{{CN|date=June 2018}} They are used to research the effects of space (cosmic radiation, weightlessness, etc.) on biological matter while in orbit around a [[celestial body]]. The first satellite carrying an animal (a dog, "[[Laika]]") was [[USSR|Soviet]] [[Sputnik 2]] on November 3, 1957. On August 20, 1960 Soviet [[Sputnik 5]] launched and recovered dogs from orbit Earth orbit.
NASA launched three satellites between 1966 and 1969 for the [[Biosatellite program]].<ref>[http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/B/Biosatellite.html Biosatellite], [[David J. Darling|David Darling]]'s ''Internet Encyclopedia of Science''</ref><ref>[http://www.astronautix.com/b/biosatellite.html Biosatellite], ''[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]''</ref>
The most famous biosatellites include: * [[Biosatellite program]] launched by [[NASA]] between 1966 and 1969. * [[Bion (satellite)|Bion space program]] by Soviet Union * The [[Mars Gravity Biosatellite]] * [[Orbiting Frog Otolith]] (OFO-A)
==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[Animals in space]] * [[Biosatellite (NASA)]]

'''Caenogenesis''' (also variously spelled '''cainogenesis''', '''cenogenesis''', '''kainogenesis''', '''kenogenesis''') is the introduction during [[embryon]]ic development of characters or structure not present in the earlier [[evolution]]ary history of the strain or [[species]], as opposed to [[palingenesis]]. Notable examples include the addition of the [[placenta]] in [[mammal]]s.
Caenogenesis constitutes a violation to [[Ernst Haeckel]]'s [[biogenetic law]] and was explained by Haeckel as adaptation to the peculiar conditions of the [[organism]]'s individual development. Other authorities, such as [[Wilhelm His, Sr.]], on the contrary saw embryonic differences as precursors to adult differences.
==See also== *[[Ontogeny]] *[[Recapitulation theory]]
==References== Gould, S.J. 1977. Ontogeny and Phylogeny. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.

{{Infobox scientist | name = Carina Curto | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1978|4|15|df=y}} | fields = [[Mathematics]]
[[Neuroscience]] | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]]
[[Duke University]] | thesis_title = Matrix Model Superpotentials and Calabi-Yau Spaces: an ADE Classification | thesis_url = https://arxiv.org/abs/math/0505111 | doctoral_advisor = [[David R. Morrison (mathematician)|David R. Morrison]]{{Cite arxiv|last=Curto|first=Carina|date=2005-05-06|title=Matrix Model Superpotentials and Calabi-Yau Spaces: an ADE Classification|eprint=math/0505111}} | known_for = [[Connectomics]] research
Network Songs | work_institutions = [[Pennsylvania State University]] }} '''Carina Curto''' (born 15 April 1978) is an American [[mathematician]], an Associate Professor at [[Pennsylvania State University]], and a [[Sloan Research Fellowship|Sloan Research Fellow]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.math.unl.edu/newsletter/data/2011Department_of_Mathematics_Newsletter.pdf|title=UNL Math News - Winter 2011|last=|first=|date=|work=Math News|access-date=2018-08-15}}{{Cite web|url=https://sites.psu.edu/mathbio/faculty/|title=Faculty {{!}} Mathematical Biology at Penn State|website=sites.psu.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-31}} She is known for her work on mathematical [[neuroscience]], including the applications of mathematics in both theoretical and [[computational neuroscience]]. Her recent work is funded by the [[BRAIN Initiative]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/mathematician-carina-curto-thinks-like-a-physicist-to-solve-neuroscience-problems-20180619/|title=Mathematician Carina Curto Thinks Like a Physicist to Solve Neuroscience Problems {{!}} Quanta Magazine|work=Quanta Magazine|access-date=2018-07-31}} She is an Associate Editor at SIAGA, a [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]] journal on Applied [[Algebra]] and [[Geometry]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.personal.psu.edu/cpc16/|title=Carina's website|website=www.personal.psu.edu|access-date=2018-07-31}} == Early life and education == Curto was born to [[Argentines|Argentine]] parents and grew up in [[Iowa City, Iowa|Iowa City]].{{Cite news|url=http://physicsoflivingsystems.org/brainstructureandfunction/bios/|title=Bios|date=2013-05-03|work=Physical and Mathematical Principles of Brain Structure and Function|access-date=2018-08-15|language=en-US}} She attended [[Iowa City West High School]]. During her school years, she attended courses at [[University of Iowa]], including advanced [[mathematics]] classes, [[physics]], [[computer science]], [[French literature]], and more.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=March 2018|title=In Honor of Women's History Month - Notices of the American Mathematical Society|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/notices/201803/201803FullIssue.pdf|journal=Notices of the American Mathematical Society|volume=65|pages=|via=}} In 1996, she began studying for an [[A.B. degree|A.B]]. in [[Physics]] at [[Harvard University]]. During her time at Harvard, she was awarded prizes including the Detur Book Prize, one of Harvard's oldest awards, and the [[American Physical Society]] minority scholarship.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aps.org/programs/minorities/honors/scholarship/prizerecipient.cfm?last_nm=Curto&first_nm=Carina&year=1997|title=Prize Recipient|website=www.aps.org|language=en|access-date=2018-08-31}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/206746689/|title=Iowa City Press-Citizen, Friday, January 16, 1998|last=|first=|date=1998-01-16|work=Iowa City Press-Citizen|access-date=2018-08-31}} After graduating from Harvard in 2000 and being awarded the [[NSF-GRF|NSF Graduate Research Fellowship]], Curto started a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]] in mathematics at [[Duke University]]. Curto's Ph.D focused on mathematical [[string theory]] and [[algebraic geometry]]. Her thesis was titled 'Matrix Model Superpotentials and [[Calabi–Yau manifold|Calabi-Yau Spaces]]: an ADE Classification'. == Career and research == Once Curto gained her Ph.D, she moved to [[Rutgers University]] in [[New Jersey]], working as a Postdoctoral Associate in a neuroscience lab at the Center for Molecular and Behavioral Neuroscience. After three years at Rutgers, she returned to working in mathematics, focusing on neuroscience from a more mathematical perspective, and moved to the [[Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences|Courant Institute of Mathematics]] at [[New York University]], then to the [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|University of Nebraska-Lincoln]], followed by the [[Pennsylvania State University]]. Curto is as an Associate Professor of mathematics, the co-head of their mathematical neuroscience lab, and a member of the Center for Neural Engineering.{{Cite web|url=http://www.math.unl.edu/research/areas/mathematical_biology/|title=Mathematical Biology {{!}} Department of Mathematics {{!}} Nebraska|last=Network|first=University of Nebraska-Lincoln {{!}} Web Developer|website=www.math.unl.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-08-31}} === Network Connectivity === Her research focuses on the interplay between the connectivity and dynamics of the [[brain]] and involves studying neural recordings and analysing the patterns of the activities. This network analysis aims to understand the connections between the [[neuron]]s and their patterns. Traditionally, neuroscientists rely on tools from [[physics]].{{Cite news|url=https://neurosciencenews.com/math-method-neural-activity-2912/|title=New Math Method Reveals Structure of Neural Activity|date=2015-10-20|work=Neuroscience News|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en-US}} But Curto's approach uses tools from pure mathematics, particularly [[algebraic geometry]], which is applied to the activity data of the neurons. Curto's research is significant in the field of [[connectomics]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.simonsfoundation.org/2018/04/02/cross-pollination-at-cosyne-2018/|title=Cross-Pollination at Cosyne 2018 {{!}} Simons Foundation|website=www.simonsfoundation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-06|date=2018-04-02}} For instance, one study showed how neural activities can drastically change by slightly changing the structure of the networks, which has implications for the study of brain disorders such as [[Parkinson's disease]] and [[schizophrenia]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.simonsfoundation.org/2018/05/03/simple-networks-generate-complex-dynamics/|title=Simple Networks Generate Complex Dynamics {{!}} Simons Foundation|website=www.simonsfoundation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-06|date=2018-05-03}} Along with Katherine Morrison from the [[University of Northern Colorado]], and with funding from the government's BRAIN Initiative grant and the [[National Science Foundation|NSF]], Curto is working on Combinatorial Threshold-Linear Networks, CTLNs. These models enable the observations of emergent patterns, such as neuronal sequences and complex rhythms, and can also be used to predict features of the dynamics, something that has been seemingly difficult to predict.{{cite arxiv|last=Morrison|first=Katherine|last2=Curto|first2=Carina|date=2018-04-04|title=Predicting neural network dynamics via graphical analysis|eprint=1804.01487|class=q-bio.NC}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.brown.edu/academics/applied-mathematics/graphs-neural-networks-and-emergent-dynamics-brain|title=Graphs, neural networks, and emergent dynamics in the brain {{!}} Division of Applied Mathematics|website=www.brown.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-03}} Aligned with her research, Curto, alongside Morrison, also created a project called Network Songs, which originally started out as a gimmick. This is a collection of songs, that show the rhythmic activity of the networks. The basis of the songs were created by assigning a note on the piano to each neuron. Curto explains that sometimes certain patterns are better distinguished by the ear, than by the eye, hence the purpose of this particular representation of the network data.{{Cite web|url=https://slideplayer.com/slide/9703374/|title=NETWORK SONGS !! created by Carina Curto & Katherine Morrison January 2016 Input: a simple directed graph G satisfying two rules: 1. G is an oriented. - ppt download|website=slideplayer.com|access-date=2018-09-03}} == Awards and personal life == Curto has been the recipient of numerous grants and awards, including becoming a [[Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation|Woodrow Wilson National Fellow]] and an [[Sloan Research Fellowship|Alfred Sloan Research Fellow]]. Additionally, in 2012, Curto was named a [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|UNL]] Academic Star.{{Cite web|url=http://www.math.unl.edu/department/awards/faculty|title=Faculty Awards {{!}} Department of Mathematics {{!}} Nebraska|last=Network|first=University of Nebraska-Lincoln {{!}} Web Developer|website=www.math.unl.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-03}} In March 2018, the [[American Mathematical Society]], AMS, included Curto in a list of 27 female mathematicians in honour of [[Women's History Month]], publishing a profile of her in the [[Notices of the American Mathematical Society|AMS Notices journal]]. Throughout her years as a mathematician, Curto has taken part in many events and boards to promote women in mathematics. This includes being involved with the Women In Math club at [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|UNL]] and being part of the Nebraska Conference for Undergraduate Women in Mathematics, NCUWM, organizing committee.{{Cite web|url=http://www.math.unl.edu/math-club/events/archive|title=Math Club Events Archive {{!}} Department of Mathematics {{!}} Nebraska|last=Network|first=University of Nebraska-Lincoln {{!}} Web Developer|website=www.math.unl.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-06}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.math.unl.edu/~ncuwm/16thAnnual/ncuwm_aboutus.php|title=Nebraska Conference for Undergraduate Women in Mathematics {{!}} About Us|last=Network|first=University of Nebraska-Lincoln {{!}} Web Developer|website=www.math.unl.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-06}} Curto is also an amateur [[tennis]] player. In 1995, when at high school, she became the Double State Champion.{{Cite web|url=https://www.iowacityschools.org/site/handlers/filedownload.ashx?moduleinstanceid=28282&dataid=38664&FileName=State%20Championships.pdf|title=Trojan Hall of Fame - Iowa City Schools|last=|first=|date=2018-05-24|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-04}} Furthermore, in 1996-1997 she was the Varsity Letter Winner for Women's tennis at Harvard. Curto lives in [[State College, Pennsylvania|State College]] with her husband and two children. == References == {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Curto, Carina}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:American women mathematicians]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University faculty]] [[Category:Computational neuroscience]] [[Category:University of Nebraska–Lincoln faculty]] [[Category:American people of Argentine descent]] [[Category:People from Iowa City, Iowa]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{short description|16th-century Archbishop of York and cardinal}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox Christian leader | type = Cardinal | honorific-prefix = His Eminence | name = Christopher Bainbridge | honorific-suffix = [[Doctor of Canon Law|D.Cn.]], [[Doctor of Civil Law|CL]] | title = [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal]], [[Archbishop of York]]
[[Primate of England]] | image =Christopher Bainbridge.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | church = | province = [[Province of York|York]] | diocese = [[Diocese of York|York]] | enthroned = 1508 (appointed) | ended = 1514 | predecessor = [[Thomas Savage (bishop)|Thomas Savage]] | successor = [[Thomas Wolsey]] | ordination = | consecration = 12 December 1507 ([[Bishop (Catholicism)|Bishop]]) | cardinal = 10 March 1511 | rank = Cardinal priest of [[Santi Marcellino e Pietro al Laterano|Santi Marcellino e Pietro]] (1511)
Cardinal priest of [[Santa Prassede]] (1511–1514) | other_post = | birth_name = | birth_date = [[circa|c.]] 1462/1464 | birth_place = [[Hilton, Cumbria|Hilton]], near [[Appleby-in-Westmorland|Appleby]], [[Westmorland]], England | death_date = 14 July 1514 (aged c. 48/50) | death_place = | buried = Chapel of St Thomas of Canterbury at the [[Venerable English College|English hospice]], Rome | nationality = English | religion = [[Roman Catholic Church]] | residence = | parents = | spouse = | children = | occupation = | profession = | alma_mater = | signature = | other = }} '''Christopher Bainbridge''' ([[circa|c.]] 1462/1464 – 1514) was an English [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church]]. He served as [[Archbishop of York]] from 1508 until his death.{{cite web |last=Miranda |first=Salvador |title=Christopher Bainbridge |url=http://www2.fiu.edu/~mirandas/bios1511.htm |work=The Cardinals of the Holy Roman Church |accessdate=26 March 2010}} ==Early life== The cardinal came from a [[Westmorland]] family with roots in [[Bainbridge, North Yorkshire]] and was a maternal nephew of [[Thomas Langton]], [[Bishop of Winchester]], which may account for his charmed early life. He was granted an [[indult]] in 1479 which allowed him to hold church [[benefice]]s while still unordained and under the age of 16, and another in 1482 that allowed him to hold more than one benefice concurrently. He was said to have been fifty years old at his death and must therefore have been born about 1464. He was described as a magister, or scientist, by 1486; at [[Bologna]] he was admitted [[Doctor of Civil Law|DCL]] in 1492; he was in Rome between 1492–1494. Appointed [[Provost (education)|Provost]] of [[Queen's College, Oxford]] in 1496, and [[Master of the Rolls]] in 1504, he was incorporated at [[Lincoln's Inn]] on 20 January 1505. By 1497, he had become chaplain to [[Henry VII of England|Henry VII]]; in 1503 [[Dean (religion)|dean]] of York; in 1505 he was [[Dean of Windsor|Dean]] of [[St. George's Chapel, Windsor]]. He was appointed [[Bishop of Durham]] on 27 August 1507. ==Archbishop of York and Cardinal== Bainbridge was [[translation (religion)|translated]] to York on 22 September 1508, a sign of the favour he enjoyed at court. On 24 September 1509, King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] (whose coronation he had attended) appointed Bainbridge to be his ambassador to [[Pope Julius II]]. Just at this time Julius had taken alarm at the invasion of Italy by [[Louis XII of France]], and the support of England was therefore of great importance. Julius left Rome to relieve [[Bologna]], and was nearly taken prisoner in the war. A group of pro-French cardinals summoned a council in opposition to him at [[Pisa]], which Julius opposed by calling another council at Rome, the [[Fifth Lateran Council]],[[Francesco Guicciardini]], Storia d'Italia, Lib.10, cap.2 in the course of which he created (in March 1511) several new Cardinals, of which Bainbridge was one, with the title of "Cardinal of St. Praxed's" or [[Santa Prassede]]. Bainbridge was immediately sent with an army to lay siege to [[Ferrara]], but the creation of the [[War of the League of Cambrai|Holy League]] relieved the papacy of some pressure by involving Spain against the French forces. Pope Julius II was succeeded on his death by [[Pope Leo X]], who was initially willing to grant the title of ''Christianissimus Rex'' (Most Christian King) to Henry, after Francis had automatically forfeited the title by waging war on the Pope. However, Henry's making peace with France in 1514 probably ended these hopes. Bainbridge died on 14 July 1514, having been poisoned by one of his own chaplains, [[Rinaldo de Modena]]. Rinaldo was imprisoned and confessed to the crime. He also implicated [[Silvestro de' Gigli|Silvester de Giglis]], then [[Bishop of Worcester]], as the instigator of the plot. De Giglis was the resident English ambassador at Rome, and regarded Bainbridge as a threat to his position: he also had sufficient power and influence to make Rinaldo retract his confession and have him killed in prison. [[Richard Pace]] and [[John Clerk (bishop)|John Clerk]], the cardinal's executors, were eager to prosecute De Giglis, but he maintained that the priest was a madman whom he had dismissed from his own service some years before in England, and his defence was accepted as sufficient. Bainbridge was buried in the chapel of St Thomas of Canterbury at the English hospice in Rome, which later became the [[Venerable English College]]. ==References== {{reflist}} *Dictionary of National Biography, 1885. * David Chambers, ''Cardinal Bainbridge in the Court of Rome,1509–1514'', London: Oxford University Press, 1965. ==External links== {{commons category|Christopher Bainbridge}} *[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02207c.htm Catholic Encyclopedia article] {{s-start}} {{s-rel|ca}} {{succession box | before=Geoffrey Blithe | title=[[Dean of York]] | after=James Harrington | years=1503–1505}} {{succession box | before=[[Christopher Urswick]] | title=[[Dean of Windsor]] | after=Thomas Hobbes | years=1505–1507}} {{succession box | before=[[William Senhouse]] | title=[[Bishop of Durham]] | after=[[Thomas Ruthall]] | years=1507–1508}} {{succession box | title=[[Archbishop of York]] | before=[[Thomas Savage (bishop)|Thomas Savage]] | after=[[Thomas Wolsey]] | years=1508–1514}} {{s-end}} {{Deans of York}} {{Deans of Windsor}} {{Bishops of Durham}} {{Archbishops of York}} {{Subject bar |portal1= Biography |portal2= Catholicism |portal3= England}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bainbridge}} [[Category:1460s births]] [[Category:1514 deaths]] [[Category:16th-century Roman Catholic archbishops]] [[Category:Archbishops of York]] [[Category:Bishops of Durham]] [[Category:Deans of Windsor]] [[Category:Deans of York]] [[Category:16th-century English bishops]] [[Category:Provosts of The Queen's College, Oxford]] [[Category:Masters of the Rolls]] [[Category:English cardinals]] [[Category:Deaths by poisoning]] [[Category:15th-century English people]] [[Category:Murdered cardinals]]
