{{redirect|Midwives}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox Occupation | name = Midwife | image = Midwife check-up.jpg | caption = A pregnant woman receives an ultrasound examination from a sonographer | official_names = Midwife<ref name="Definition">{{cite web |title= International Definition of the Midwife |url= http://www.internationalmidwives.org/who-we-are/policy-and-practice/icm-international-definition-of-the-midwife/ |publisher= International Confederation of Midwives |accessdate= 2015 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170922213449/http://internationalmidwives.org/who-we-are/policy-and-practice/icm-international-definition-of-the-midwife/ |archivedate= 22 September 2017 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> | type = [[Professional]] | activity_sector = [[Midwifery]], [[obstetrics]], newborn care, [[women's health]], [[reproductive health]] | competencies = Knowledge, professional behaviour and specific skills in family planning, pregnancy, labour, birth, postpartum period, newborn care, women's health, reproductive health, and social, epidemiologic and cultural context of midwifery<ref name="Essential Competencies">{{cite web | url=http://internationalmidwives.org/what-we-do/education-coredocuments/essential-competencies-basic-midwifery-practice/ | title=Essential Competencies for Basic Midwifery Practice | publisher=International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) | accessdate=2015 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171008161840/http://internationalmidwives.org/what-we-do/education-coredocuments/essential-competencies-basic-midwifery-practice | archivedate=8 October 2017 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> | formation = * Bachelor of Midwifery * Master of Midwifery | employment_field = hospitals, clinics, health units, maternity units, birth centers, private practices, home births, community, etc | related_occupation = [[obstetrician]], [[gynecologist]], [[pediatrician]] }}
A '''midwife''' is a [[health professional]] specializing in [[pregnancy]], [[childbirth]], [[postpartum]], women's sexual and [[reproductive health]] (including annual [[gynecology|gynecological]] exams, [[family planning]], [[menopausal]] care and others), and newborn care.<ref name="Definition"/><ref name="Essential Competencies"/> Their education and training in [[midwifery]] equips them to recognise the variations of normal progress of labor, and understand how to deal with deviations from normal. They may intervene in high risk situations such as [[breech birth]]s, [[twin birth]]s and births where the baby is in a [[Presentation (obstetrics)|posterior position]], using non-invasive techniques. When a pregnant woman requires care beyond the midwife's [[scope of practice]], they refer women to [[obstetricians]] or [[Maternal-fetal medicine|perinatologists]], who are [[medical specialist]]s in complications related to pregnancy and birth, including surgical and instrumental deliveries.<ref name="business-being-born">{{cite news|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2008/01/09/movies/09born.html|title=The Business of Being Born (film)|last=Epstein|first=Abby|accessdate=30 October 2009|work=The New York Times|date=9 January 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213155538/http://movies.nytimes.com/2008/01/09/movies/09born.html|archivedate=13 February 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title=Midwifery around the World: A study in the role of midwives in local communities and healthcare systems|last=Carson|first=A|date=May–June-2016|website=annals of global health|publisher=Elsevier Inc|doi=10.1016/j.aogh.2016.04.617|volume=82|page=381}}</ref> In many parts of the world, these professions work in tandem to provide care to childbearing women. In others, only the midwife is available to provide care, and in yet other countries many women elect to utilize obstetricians primarily over midwives.
Many [[developing countries]] are investing money and training for midwives as these services are needed all over the world. Some [[primary care]] services are currently lacking due to the shortage of money being funded for these resources.
== Definition and etymology== According to the definition of the [[International Confederation of Midwives]], which has also been adopted by the [[World Health Organization]] and the [[International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics]]:<ref name="Definition"/>
{{quote|A midwife is a person who has successfully completed a [[midwifery]] education programme that is recognised in the country where it is located and that is based on the ICM Essential Competencies for Basic Midwifery Practice<ref name="Essential Competencies"/> and the framework of the ICM Global Standards for Midwifery Education;<ref name="Global Standards">{{cite web | url=http://internationalmidwives.org/what-we-do/education-coredocuments/global-standards-education/ | title=Global Standards for Basic Midwifery Education | publisher=International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) | accessdate=2015 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170925091426/http://internationalmidwives.org/what-we-do/education-coredocuments/global-standards-education/ | archivedate=25 September 2017 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> who has acquired the requisite qualifications to be registered and/or legally licensed to practice [[midwifery]] and use the title ‘midwife’; and who demonstrates competency in the practice of [[midwifery]].}}
The word derives from [[Old English]] ''[[wikt:mid#Old English|mid]]'', "with" and ''[[wikt:wif#Old English|wif]]'', "woman", and thus originally meant "with-woman", that is, the person who is ''with'' the ''mother'' (woman) at childbirth.<ref>{{cite web|title= midwife|url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/118259|publisher=The Oxford English Dictionary|accessdate=2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Midwife: Word History|url= https://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=midwife|publisher= The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language, Fifth Edition. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Publishing Company|date= 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150921145947/https://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=midwife|archivedate= 21 September 2015|df= dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=midwife |url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=midwife |work=The Online Etymological Dictionary |last=Harper |first=Douglas |authorlink=Douglas Harper |accessdate=2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915024206/http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=midwife |archivedate=15 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The word is used to refer to both male and female midwives.
==Scope of practice== [[File:Worldwide Midwives.png|thumb|250px|The 112 countries containing member associations of the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) in 2017<ref>{{cite web |title= Midwives Associations Worldwide |url= http://www.internationalmidwives.org/our-members/ |publisher= International Confederation of Midwives |accessdate=6 March 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180113150313/http://internationalmidwives.org/our-members/ |archivedate= 13 January 2018 |df= dmy-all }}</ref>]] The midwife is recognised as a responsible and accountable professional who works in partnership with women to give the necessary support, care and advice during pregnancy, labour and the postpartum period, to conduct births on the midwife’s own responsibility and to provide care for the newborn and the infant. This care includes preventative measures, the promotion of normal birth, the detection of complications in mother and child, the accessing of medical care or other appropriate assistance and the carrying out of emergency measures.
The midwife has an important task in health counselling and education, not only for the woman, but also within the family and the community. This work should involve antenatal education and preparation for parenthood and may extend to women’s health, sexual or reproductive health and child care.
A midwife may practise in any setting including the home, community, hospitals, clinics or health units.<ref name="Definition"/>
==Education, training, regulation and practice==
===Australia=== '''Education, training and regulation'''
The undergraduate [[midwifery]] programs are three-year full-time university programs leading to a bachelor's degree in midwifery (Bachelor of Midwifery) with additional one-year full-time programs leading to an honours bachelor's degree in midwifery (Bachelor of Midwifery (Honours)).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ahpra.gov.au/Education/Approved-Programs-of-Study.aspx |title=Approved Programs of Study |publisher=Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526032729/http://www.ahpra.gov.au/Education/Approved-Programs-of-Study.aspx |archivedate=26 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The postgraduate midwifery programs (for registered midwives) lead to master's degrees in midwifery (Master in Midwifery, Master in Midwifery (Research), MSc Midwifery). There are also postgraduate midwifery programs (for registered nurses who wish to become midwives) leading to a bachelor's degree or equivalent qualification in midwifery (Bachelor of Midwifery, Graduate Diploma in Midwifery).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.midwivesaustralia.com.au/?page_id=224 |title=Becoming a Midwife |publisher=Midwives Australia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160605072655/http://www.midwivesaustralia.com.au/?page_id=224 |archivedate=5 June 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Midwives in Australia must be registered with the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency in order to practice [[midwifery]] and use the title 'midwife' or 'registered midwife'.
'''Practice'''
Midwives work in a number of settings including hospitals, birthing centres, community centres and women’s homes. They may be employed by health services or organisations, or self-employed as privately practising midwives. All midwives are expected to work within a defined scope of practice and conform to ongoing regulatory requirements that ensure they are safe and autonomous practitioners.
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * Australian College of Midwives (ACM).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.midwives.org.au/ |title=Australian College of Midwives (ACM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029234555/http://www.midwives.org.au/ |archivedate=29 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Canada===
Midwifery was reintroduced as a regulated profession in most of [[Canada]]'s ten provinces in the 1990s.<ref>{{cite book |last=Schroff |first=F. |year=1997 |title=The New Midwifery |location=Toronto |publisher=Women's Press |isbn=0-88961-224-2 }}</ref> Prior to this legalization, some midwives had practiced in a legal "grey area" in some provinces.<ref name="sask">[https://www.saskatchewanmidwives.com/midwifery-in-saskatchewan/ Midwifery in Saskatchewan], Midwives Association of Saskatchewan</ref> In 1981, a midwife in BC was charged with practicing without a medical license.<ref name="mic">[https://www.lawnow.org/midwifery-canada/ Midwifery in Canada], Law Now</ref>
After several decades of intensive political [[lobbying]] by midwives and consumers, fully integrated, regulated and publicly funded [[midwifery]] is now part of the health system in the provinces of [[British Columbia]] (regulated since 1995), [[Alberta]] (regulated since 2000, fully funded since 2009) [[Saskatchewan]] (regulated since 1999), [[Manitoba]] (regulated since 1997), [[Ontario]] (regulated since 1991), [[Quebec]] (regulated since 1999), and [[Nova Scotia]] (regulated since 2006), and in the [[Northwest Territories]] (regulated since 2003) and [[Nunavut]](regulated since 2008).<ref name="mic"/> In 2010, Midwifery legislation was proclaimed in [[New Brunswick]] and [[Newfoundland and Labrador]]. Only [[Prince Edward Island]] and [[Yukon]] have no legislation in place for the practice of [[midwifery]].<ref name="mic"/>
====Education, training and regulation====
The undergraduate [[midwifery]] programs are four-year full-time university programs leading to bachelor's degrees in midwifery (B.H.Sc. in Midwifery, Bachelor of Midwifery).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canadianmidwives.org/midwifery-education.html |title=Midwifery Education in Canada |publisher=Canadian Association of Midwives (CAM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121150504/http://www.canadianmidwives.org/midwifery-education.html |archivedate=21 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In British Columbia, the program is offered at the [[University of British Columbia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.midwifery.ubc.ca|title=Home - Midwifery Program|author=|date=|website=www.midwifery.ubc.ca|accessdate=2 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307230944/https://midwifery.ubc.ca/|archivedate=7 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Mount Royal University in Calgary, Alberta offers a Bachelor of Midwifery program. In Ontario, the Midwifery Education Program (MEP) is offered by a consortium of [[McMaster University]], [[Ryerson University]] and [[Laurentian University]]. In Manitoba the program is offered by [[University College of the North]]. In [[Quebec]], the program is offered at the [[Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières]]. In northern Quebec and Nunavut, Inuit women are being educated to be midwives in their own communities.{{fact|date=June 2018}}
There are also "bridging programs" for internationally educated midwives at [[Ryerson University]] in Ontario and at the University of British Columbia. A federally funded pilot project called the Multi-jurisdictional Midwifery Bridging Program<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.midwiferybridging.ca |title=midwiferybridging.ca |publisher=midwiferybridging.ca |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> has been offered in [[Western Canada]] in the past, but funding was discontinued when they expanded their midwifery program. A new program was reinstated through the University of British Columbia in 2016 called the Internationally Educated Midwives Bridging Program IEMBP.
Midwives in Canada must be registered, after a process of assessment by the provincial regulatory bodies, in order to practice [[midwifery]] and use the title 'midwife', 'registered midwife' or, the French-language equivalent, 'sage femme'.
====Practice====
From the original 'alternative' style of [[midwifery]] in the 1960s and 1970s, [[midwifery]] practice is offered in a variety of ways within regulated provinces: midwives offer continuity of care within small group practices, choice of birthplace, and a focus on the woman as the primary decision-maker in her maternity care. When women or their newborns experience complications, midwives will work in consultation with an appropriate specialist. Registered midwives have access to appropriate diagnostics like blood tests and ultrasounds and can prescribe some medications. Founding principles of the Canadian model of [[midwifery]] include informed choice, choice of birthplace, continuity of care from a small group of midwives and respect for the woman as the primary decision maker. Midwives typically have hospital privileges and support women's right to choose where she will have her baby.{{citation needed|date=November 2010}}
The legal recognition of [[midwifery]] has brought midwives into the mainstream of [[health care in Canada|health care]] with universal funding for services, hospital privileges, rights to prescribe medications commonly needed during pregnancy, birth and postpartum, and rights to order blood work and ultrasounds for their own clients and full consultation access to physicians. To protect the tenets of [[midwifery]] and support midwives to provide woman-centered care, the regulatory bodies and [[Professional body|professional associations]] have legislation and standards in place to provide protection, particularly for choice of birth [[home birth|place]], informed choice and continuity of care. All regulated midwives have malpractice insurance. Any unregulated person who provides care with 'restricted acts' in regulated provinces or territories is practicing [[midwifery]] without a license and is subject to investigation and prosecution.
Prior to legislative changes, very few Canadian women had access to [[midwifery]] care, in part because it was not funded by the [[health care system]]. Legalizing [[midwifery]] has made midwifery services available to a wide and diverse population of women and in many communities the number of available midwives does not meet the growing demand for services. [[Midwifery]] services are free to women living in provinces and territories with regulated [[midwifery]].
The national professional associations in Canada is the Canadian Association of Midwives (CAM).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canadianmidwives.org/ |title=Canadian Association of Midwives (CAM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151109174414/http://www.canadianmidwives.org/ |archivedate=9 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====British Columbia====
On 16 March 1995, the BC government announced the approval of regulations governing [[midwifery]] and establishing the College of Midwives of BC. In 1996, the Health Professional Council released a draft of Bylaws for the College of Midwives of BC which received Cabinet approval on 13 April 1997. In 1998, midwives were officially registered with the College of Midwives of BC.<ref name="cmbc.bc.ca">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmbc.bc.ca |title=cmbc.bc.ca |publisher=cmbc.bc.ca |date=1 January 1998 |accessdate=10 December 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130917090243/http://www.cmbc.bc.ca/ |archivedate=17 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In BC, midwives are primary care providers for women in all stages of pregnancy, from prenatal to six weeks postpartum. Midwives also care for newborns. To see the approximate proportion of women whose primary birth attendant was a midwife in British Columbia see, "What Mothers Say: The Canadian Maternity Experiences Survey. Public Health Agency of Canada. Ottawa, 2009, p. 115.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/rhs-ssg/pdf/survey-eng.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-09-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170610144203/http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/rhs-ssg/pdf/survey-eng.pdf |archivedate=10 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Midwives in BC can deliver natural births in hospitals or homes. If a complication arises in a pregnancy, labour, birth or postpartum, a midwife will consult with a specialist such as an obstetrician or paediatrician. Core competencies and restricted activities are included in the BC Health Professions Act Midwives Regulation. As of April 2009, the scope of practice for midwives allows them to prescribe certain prescription drugs, use acupuncture for pain relief, assist a surgeon in a caesarean section delivery and to perform a vacuum extraction delivery. These specialized practices require additional education and certification.
As of November 2015, the College of Midwives of British Columbia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmbc.bc.ca/pdf.shtml?List-of-Registrants|title=Register of Current & Former Registrants |publisher=College of Midwives of British Columbia |accessdate=12 November 2015}}</ref> reported 247 General, 2 Temporary, 46 Non-practicing Registrant midwives. There were 2 midwives per 100,000 people in BC in 2006.<ref>Canadian Institute for Health Information document titled, Number of Health Personnel in Selected Professions by Registration Status, 2006. This data has the following proviso, "Due to the variation in regulatory requirements, interprofessional comparison should be interpreted with caution."</ref>
A midwife must be registered with the College of Midwives of BC in order to practice. To continue licensure midwives must maintain regular recertification in neonatal resuscitation and management of maternal emergencies, maintain the minimum volume of clinical care (40 women), participate in peer case reviews and continuing education activities.<ref name="cmbc.bc.ca"/>
The University of British Columbia (UBC) has a four-year Bachelor of Midwifery program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.midwifery.ubc.ca/midwifery.htm|title=Home - Midwifery Program|author=|date=|website=www.midwifery.ubc.ca|accessdate=2 May 2018}}</ref> The UBC [[midwifery]] program is poised to double in size thanks to an increase in government funding. Graduation of students will increase to 20 per year.
In terms of proffesional associations, BC has both the College of Midwives of BC<ref name="cmbc.bc.ca"/> and the Midwives Association of BC<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcmidwives.com |title=bcmidwives.com |publisher=bcmidwives.com |accessdate=10 December 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021021749/http://www.bcmidwives.com/ |archivedate=21 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===France=== [[File:Sages-femmes.jpg|thumb|Two French midwives (sages-femmes)]] '''Education, training and regulation'''
The undergraduate [[midwifery]] programs are five-year full-time university programs (four years in midwifery schools after a first year of medical studies common with Medicine, Odontology and Pharmacy) leading to an accredited master's degree in midwifery (Diplôme d'Etat de Sage-Femme).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordre-sages-femmes.fr/etre-sage-femme/formation/initiale/|title=La formation initiale|publisher=Ordre des sages-femmes|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222150550/http://www.ordre-sages-femmes.fr/etre-sage-femme/formation/initiale/|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Midwives in France must be registered with the Ordre des sages-femmes<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ordre-sages-femmes.fr/ |title=Ordre des sages-femmes |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515051832/http://www.ordre-sages-femmes.fr/ |archivedate=15 May 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> in order to practice midwifery and use the title 'sage-femme'.
'''Practice'''
Midwives (''sage-femmes'' "wise women" or ''maïeuticien''/''maïeuticienne'') are independent practitioners, specialists in birth and women's medicine.
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * L'Ordre des Sages-Femmes, Conseil National.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ordre-sages-femmes.fr/ |title=L'Ordre des Sages-Femmes, Conseil National |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515051832/http://www.ordre-sages-femmes.fr/ |archivedate=15 May 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Collège National des Sages-Femmes de France (CNSF).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnsf.asso.fr/ |title=Collège National des Sages-Femmes de France (CNSF) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117031424/http://www.cnsf.asso.fr/ |archivedate=17 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Société Française de Maïeutique (SFMa).
===Ireland=== '''Education, training and regulation'''
The undergraduate [[midwifery]] programs are four-year full-time university programs, with an internship in the final year, leading to an honours bachelor's degree in midwifery (BSc (Hons) Midwifery).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nursingboard.ie/en/edu-pre_reg.aspx |title=Pre-Registration Programmes |publisher=The Nursing and Midwifery Board of Ireland (NMBI) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122031442/http://www.nursingboard.ie/en/edu-pre_reg.aspx |archivedate=22 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The postgraduate midwifery programs (for registered midwives) lead to master's degrees in midwifery (MSc Midwifery, MSc Midwifery Practice). There are also postgraduate midwifery programs (for registered general nurses who wish to become midwives) leading to a qualification in midwifery (Higher Diploma in Midwifery).
Midwives must be registered with the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Ireland (NMBI) in order to practice midwifery and use the title 'midwife' or 'registered midwife'.
===Japan===
'''Education, training and regulation'''
[[Midwifery]] was first regulated in 1868. Today midwives in Japan are regulated under the Act on Public Health Nurse, Midwife and Nurse (No. 203) established in 1948. Japanese midwives must pass a national certification exam. On 1 March 2003 the Japanese name of midwife officially converted to unisex name. Still, only women can take the national exam to be midwives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.midwife.or.jp/general/what.html|title=Japanese Midwives Association|language=Japanese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001141310/http://www.midwife.or.jp/general/what.html|archivedate=1 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * Japanese Midwives Association (JMA).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.midwife.or.jp/ |title=Japanese Midwives Association (JMA) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001162953/http://www.midwife.or.jp/ |archivedate=1 October 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Japan Academy of Midwifery (JAM).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://square.umin.ac.jp/jam/ |title=Japan Academy of Midwifery (JAM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919150418/http://square.umin.ac.jp/jam/ |archivedate=19 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Japanese Nursing Association (JNA), Midwives' Division.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nurse.or.jp/jna/english/midwifery/ |title=Japanese Nursing Association (JNA), Midwives' Division |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117030213/http://www.nurse.or.jp/jna/english/midwifery/ |archivedate=17 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:The National Archives UK - CO 1069-157-11 cropped.jpg|thumb|250px|Tanzanian midwife weighing an infant and giving advice to the mother]]
=== Mozambique === When a 16-year civil war ended in 1992, Mozambique's health care system was devastated and one in ten women were dying in childbirth. There were only 18 [[obstetrician]]s for a population of 19 million. In 2004, Mozambique introduced a new health care initiative to train midwives in emergency obstetric care in an attempt to guarantee access to quality medical care during pregnancy and childbirth. The newly introduced midwives system now perform major surgeries including [[Cesareans]] and [[hysterectomies]].
As the figures now stand, Mozambique is one of the few countries on track to achieve the [[United Nations Millennium Development Goal|MDG]] of reducing the maternal death rate by 75% by 2015.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wnet/wideangle/episodes/birth-of-a-surgeon/introduction/747/ PBS documentary ''Birth of a Surgeon''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225081550/http://www.pbs.org/wnet/wideangle/episodes/birth-of-a-surgeon/introduction/747/ |date=25 December 2014 }} </ref>
===Netherlands=== '''Education, training and regulation'''
The undergraduate [[midwifery]] programs are four-year full-time university programs leading to a bachelor's degree in midwifery (HBO-bachelor Verloskunde).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.knov.nl/samenwerken/tekstpagina/489/midwifery-in-the-netherlands/|publisher=The Royal Dutch Organisation of Midwives (KNOV): |title=Midwifery in the Netherlands}}</ref> There are four colleges for midwifery in the Netherlands: in Amsterdam, Groningen, Rotterdam and Maastricht. Midwives are called ''vroedvrouw'' (knowledge woman), ''vroedmeester'' (knowledge master, male), or ''verloskundige'' (deliverance experts) in Dutch.
'''Practice'''
Midwives are independent specialists in physiologic birth. In the Netherlands, home birth is still a common practice, although rates have been declining during the past decades. Between 2005-2008, 29% of babies were delivered at home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.nl/en-GB/menu/themas/gezondheid-welzijn/publicaties/artikelen/archief/2009/2009-2696-wm.htm?Languageswitch=on|publisher=CVZ, Central Bureau of Statistics|title=Fewer women give birth at home|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001075455/http://www.cbs.nl/en-GB/menu/themas/gezondheid-welzijn/publicaties/artikelen/archief/2009/2009-2696-wm.htm?Languageswitch=on|archivedate=1 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This figure fell to 23% delivered at home between 2007-2010 according to [[Midwifery]] in the Netherlands, a 2012 pamphlet by The Royal Dutch Organization for Midwives.<ref name="The Royal Dutch Organization of Midwives">{{cite web|title=Midwifery in the Netherlands |url=http://www.knov.nl/docs/uploads/Midwifery_in_The__Netherlands__20120730__groot.pdf |publisher=(KNOV)|accessdate=2012}}</ref> In 2014 it has dropped further to 13.4%.[https://assets.perined.nl/docs/353d9249-9875-4cb3-9c86-f078ae3f7aef.pdf perined.nl/jaarboek2104.pdf].
Midwives are generally organized as private practices, some of those are hospital-based. In-hospital outpatient childbirth is available in most hospitals. In this case, a woman's own midwife delivers the baby at the delivery room of a hospital, without intervention of an obstetrician. In all settings, midwives will transfer care to an obstetrician in case of a complicated childbirth or need for emergency intervention.
Apart from childbirth and immediate postpartum care, midwives are the first line of care in pregnancy control and education of mothers-to-be. Typical information that is given to mothers includes information about food, alcohol, life style, travel, hobbies, sex, etc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.verloskundigestadspraktijk.nl/ |language=Dutch |publisher= |title=Obstetric Practice in the City of Groningen}}</ref> Some [[midwifery]] practices give additional care in the form of preconceptional care and help with fertility problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dutchmidwife.com/voor-zwangeren/zwanger-worden/kinderwensspreekuur/|language=Dutch|title=Preconceptional care|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113201201/http://www.dutchmidwife.com/voor-zwangeren/zwanger-worden/kinderwensspreekuur/|archivedate=13 November 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
All care by midwives is legal and it is totally reimbursed by all insurance companies. This includes prenatal care, childbirth (by midwives or obstetricians, at home or in the hospital), as well as postpartum/postnatal care for mother and baby at home.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.expatarrivals.com/article/having-a-baby-in-the-netherlands |title=Having a baby in the Netherlands |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010084408/http://www.expatarrivals.com/article/having-a-baby-in-the-netherlands |archivedate=10 October 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cvz.nl/zorgpakket |publisher=CVZ, College for Healthcare Insurances |title=Care package}}</ref>
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * Royal Dutch Organisation of Midwives | Koninklijke Nederlandse Organisatie van Verloskundigen (KNOV).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knov.nl/ |title=Royal Dutch Organisation of Midwives - Koninklijke Nederlandse Organisatie van Verloskundigen (KNOV)}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== [[Midwifery]] is a regulated profession with no connection to Nursing. Midwifery is a profession with a distinct body of knowledge and its own scope of practice, code of ethics and standards of practice. The midwifery profession has knowledge, skills and abilities to provide a primary complete maternity service to childbearing women on its own responsibility.
'''Education, training and regulation'''
The undergraduate [[midwifery]] programmes are three-year full-time (three trimesters per year) tertiary programmes leading to a bachelor's degree in midwifery (Bachelor of Midwifery or Bachelor of Health Science (Midwifery)).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.midwife.org.nz/education/where-to-start-becoming-a-midwife |title=Where to Start... Becoming a Midwife |publisher=New Zealand College of Midwives |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121185138/https://www.midwife.org.nz/education/where-to-start-becoming-a-midwife |archivedate=21 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> These programmes are offered by [[Otago Polytechnic]] in Dunedin, [[Ara Institute of Canterbury]] (formally CPIT) in Christchurch, [[Waikato Institute of Technology]] in Hamilton and [[Auckland University of Technology]] (AUT) in Auckland. Several schools have satellite programmes such as Otago with a programme in Southland, Wanaka, Wellington, Palmerston North, Wanganui, and Wairarapa - and AUT with student cohorts in various sites in the upper North Island.<ref name="New Zealand College of Midwives"/> The postgraduate midwifery programmes (for registered midwives) lead to postgraduate degrees or equivalent qualifications in midwifery (Postgraduate Certificate in Midwifery, Postgraduate Diploma in Midwifery, Master of Midwifery, PhD Professional Doctorate).
The Midwifery First Year of Practice Programme (MFYP) is a compulsory national programme for all New Zealand registered midwifery graduates, irrespective of work setting. The New Zealand College of Midwives (the NZCOM) is contracted by the funder, Health Workforce New Zealand (HWNZ), to provide the programme nationally in accordance with the programme specification.<ref>{{cite web |title= The Midwifery First Year of Practice Programme |url= https://www.midwife.org.nz/quality-practice/midwifery-first-year-of-practice/ |publisher= New Zealand College of Midwives |accessdate= 2015 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180128211540/https://www.midwife.org.nz/quality-practice/midwifery-first-year-of-practice |archivedate= 28 January 2018 |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
Midwives in New Zealand must be registered with the Midwifery Council of New Zealand in order to practice [[midwifery]] and use the title 'midwife'.
'''Practice'''
Women may choose a midwife, a [[General practitioner|General Practitioner]] or an Obstetrician to provide their maternity care. About 78 percent choose a midwife (8 percent GP, 8 percent Obstetrician, 6 percent unknown).<ref>New Zealand Health Information Service: "Report on Maternity - Maternal and Newborn Information 2003."</ref> Midwives provide maternity care from early pregnancy to 6 weeks postpartum. The [[midwifery]] scope of practise covers normal pregnancy and birth. The midwife will either consult or transfer care where there is a departure from a normal pregnancy. Antenatal care is normally provided in clinics, and postnatal care is initially provided in the woman’s home. Birth can be in the home, a primary birthing unit, or a hospital. [[Midwifery]] care is fully funded by the Government. (GP care may be fully funded. Private obstetric care will incur a fee in addition to the government funding.)
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * New Zealand College of Midwives.<ref name="New Zealand College of Midwives">{{cite web |url=https://www.midwife.org.nz/ |title=New Zealand College of Midwives |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001115501/https://www.midwife.org.nz/ |archivedate=1 October 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Somalia === Increase in midwifery education has led to advances in impoverished countries. In [[Somalia]], 1 in 14 women die while giving birth.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/features/2013/somalia_skilled_birth_attendants/en/|title=WHO {{!}} Midwives at heart of Somalia’s new reproductive health strategy|website=www.who.int|access-date=2016-12-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220190840/http://www.who.int/features/2013/somalia_skilled_birth_attendants/en/|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Senior reproductive and maternal health adviser at UNFPA, Achu Lordfred claims, “the severe shortage of skilled health personnel with obstetric and midwifery skills means the most have their babies delivered by traditional birth attendants. But, when complications arise, these women either die or develop debilitating conditions, such as obstetric fistula, or lose their babies.” UNFPA is striving to change these odds by opening seven midwifery schools and training 125 midwives so far.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/91/11/13-021113/en/|title=WHO {{!}} More midwives needed to improve maternal and newborn survival|website=www.who.int|access-date=2016-11-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110104754/http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/91/11/13-021113/en/|archivedate=10 November 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===South Africa=== {{Main article|Midwives in South Africa}}
'''Education, training and regulation'''
Training includes aspects of midwifery, general nursing, community nursing and psychiatry, and can be achieved as either a four-year degree or a four-year diploma.<ref name="sanc">http://www.sanc.co.za {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180224034911/http://sanc.co.za/ |date=24 February 2018 }} 5 June 2017.</ref> *Advanced Diploma in Midwifery: Holders of this qualification are eligible to register with the SANC as midwives. Assessments are conducted in line with the assessment policy of the Regulations Relating to the Accreditation of Institutions as Nursing Education Institutions (NEI). This qualification allows international employability. * Postgraduate Diploma in Midwifery: The Postgraduate Diploma articulates with a Masters Degree in Nursing at NQF level 9. This qualification allows international employability. *Bachelor’s Degree in Nursing and Midwifery: Holders of this qualification are eligible for registration with the SANC as a Professional Nurse and Midwife. This qualification allows international employability.
The midwifery profession is regulated under the Nursing Act, Act No 3 of 2005. The South African Nursing Council (SANC) is the regulatory body of midwifery in South Africa.
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * The Society of Midwives of South Africa (SOMSA).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.midwivessociety.co.za/ |title=The Society of Midwives of South Africa (SOMSA) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170922134903/http://midwivessociety.co.za/ |archivedate=22 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Tanzania=== '''Education, training and regulation'''
There are different levels of education for midwives:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tnmc.go.tz/data/Download/Scope%20of%20Practice%20for%20Nurses%20and%20Midwives%20in%20Tanzania.pdf |title=Scope of Practice for Nurses and Midwives in Tanzania |publisher=Tanzania Nursing and Midwifery Council |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171022142402/http://www.tnmc.go.tz/data/Download/Scope%20of%20Practice%20for%20Nurses%20and%20Midwives%20in%20Tanzania.pdf |archivedate=22 October 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Certificate in Midwifery. * Diploma in Midwifery. * Advanced Diploma in Midwifery. * Bachelor of Science in Midfwifery (BScM). * Master of Science in Midwifery (MScM).
Midwives must be licensed by the Tanzania Nursing and Midwifery Council (TNMC) in order to practice as a 'registered midwife' or 'enrolled midwife'.<ref name="TanzaniaAct">{{cite web |url=http://www.tnmc.go.tz/data/Download/The%20Nursing%20And%20Midwifery%20Act.%202010.pdf |title=The Nursing and Midwifery Act, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171022141952/http://www.tnmc.go.tz/data/Download/The%20Nursing%20And%20Midwifery%20Act.%202010.pdf |archivedate=22 October 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> TNMC ensure the quality midwifery education output, develop and reviews various guidelines and standards on midwifery professionals and monitor their implementation, monitor and evaluate midwifery education programs and approve such programs to meet the Council and international requirements. Also it establish standards of proficiencies for midwifery education.<ref name= "TanzaniaAct"/>
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * Tanzania Midwives Association (TAMA).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tama.co.tz/ |title=Tanzania Midwives Association (TAMA) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005000535/http://tama.co.tz/ |archivedate=5 October 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== '''Education, training and regulation'''
The undergraduate [[midwifery]] programs are three-year full-time university programs leading to honours bachelor's degrees in midwifery: BSc (Hons) Midwifery, Bachelor of Midwifery (Hons).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nmc.org.uk/education/becoming-a-nurse-or-midwife/becoming-a-midwife/ |title=Becoming a midwife |publisher=The Nursing and Midwifery Council |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118040809/http://www.nmc.org.uk/education/becoming-a-nurse-or-midwife/becoming-a-midwife |archivedate=18 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The postgraduate midwifery programs (for registered midwives) lead to master's degrees in midwifery (MSc Midwifery, MSc Advanced Practice Midwifery). There are also undergraduate and postgraduate midwifery programs (for graduates with a relevant degree who wish to become midwives) leading to degrees or equivalent qualifications in midwifery (BSc (Hons) Midwifery, Bachelor of Midwifery (Hons), Graduate Diploma in Midwifery, Postgraduate Diploma in Midwifery, MSc Midwifery). [[Midwifery]] training consists of classroom-based learning provided by select universities<ref>{{cite web|url=https://studentmidwife.net/tobe/universities.330/|title=Midwifery Universities in the UK|author=|date=|website=studentmidwife.net|accessdate=2 May 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117032348/https://studentmidwife.net/tobe/universities.330/|archivedate=17 November 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> in conjunction with hospital- and community-based training placements at [[NHS Trusts]].
[[Midwifery]] students do not pay tuition fees and are eligible for additional financial support while training. Funding varies depending on which country within the UK the student is located in: students are eligible for NHS bursaries in addition to a grant of 1,000 pounds a year, and neither has to be repaid.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/EducationAndLearning/UniversityAndHigherEducation/StudentFinance/Typesoffinance/DG_171537 |title=Student Finance, Loans and Universities - GOV.UK |publisher=Direct.gov.uk |date=1 September 2012 |accessdate=10 December 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003032953/http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/EducationAndLearning/UniversityAndHigherEducation/StudentFinance/Typesoffinance/DG_171537 |archivedate=3 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Shortened-course students, who are already registered adult nurses, have different funding arrangements, are employed by the local NHS Trust via the Strategic Health Authority (SHA), and are paid salaries. This varies between universities and SHAs, with some students being paid their pre-training salaries, while others are employed as a Band 5 and still others are paid a proportion of a Band 5 salary.
Midwives must be registered with the [[Nursing and Midwifery Council]] in order to practice [[midwifery]] and use the title 'midwife' or 'registered midwife', and must also have a Supervisor of Midwives through their local supervising authority.
'''Practice'''
Midwives are practitioners in their own right in the [[United Kingdom]]. They take responsibility for the [[antenatal]], [[childbirth|intrapartum]] and [[postnatal]] care of women up until 28 days after the birth, or as required thereafter. Midwives are the lead [[Health profession|health care professional]] attending the majority of births, whether at home, in a midwife-led unit or in a hospital (although most births in the UK occur in hospitals).
In December 2014 the [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]] updated its guidance regarding where women should give birth. The new guidance states that midwife-led units are safer than hospitals for women having straightforward (low risk) pregnancies. Its updated guidance also confirms that home birth is as safe as birth in a midwife-led unit or a traditional labour ward for the babies of low-risk pregnant women who have already had at least one child previously.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nice.org.uk/news/press-and-media/midwife-care-during-labour-safest-women-straightforward-pregnancies|title=NICE confirms midwife-led care during labour is safest for women with straightforward pregnancies|author=|date=|website=nice.org.uk|accessdate=2 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105213256/https://www.nice.org.uk/news/press-and-media/midwife-care-during-labour-safest-women-straightforward-pregnancies|archivedate=5 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Intrapartum Care">{{cite web|url=http://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg190/evidence/cg190-intrapartum-care-full-guideline3 |title=Care of Healthy Women and Their Babies During Childbirth |publisher=National Institute for Health and Care Excellence |work=National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health |date=December 2014 |accessdate=21 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212090530/http://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg190/evidence/cg190-intrapartum-care-full-guideline3 |archivedate=12 February 2015 |df= }}</ref>
Many midwives also work in the community. The role of community midwives includes making initial appointments with pregnant women, managing [[clinic]]s, undertaking postnatal care in the home and attending [[home birth]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rcm.org.uk/college/your-career/students/student-life-e-newsletter/student-life-october-2010/career-profile-community-midwife/?locale=en |title=Career Profile: Community Midwife - Royal College of Midwives |publisher=Rcm.org.uk |accessdate=10 December 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101022138/http://www.rcm.org.uk/college/your-career/students/student-life-e-newsletter/student-life-october-2010/career-profile-community-midwife/?locale=en |archivedate=1 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A community midwife typically has a pager, is responsible for a particular area and can be contacted by ambulance control when needed. Sometimes they are paged to help out in a hospital when there are insufficient midwives available.
Most midwives work within the [[National Health Service]], providing both hospital and community care, but a significant proportion work independently, providing total care for their clients within a community setting. However, recent government proposals to require insurance for all health professionals is threatening independent [[midwifery]] in England.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/6435279.stm |title=Threat to Independent Midwifery |publisher=BBC News |date=10 March 2007 |accessdate=10 December 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130408062448/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/6435279.stm |archivedate=8 April 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Midwives are at all times responsible for the women they are caring for. They must know when to refer complications to medical staff, act as the women's advocate, and ensure that mothers retain choice and control over [[childbirth]].
Most practising midwives in the United Kingdom are female: men account for less than 0.5 per cent of midwives on the register of the [[Nursing and Midwifery Council|NMC]].<ref>http://www.nmc-uk.org/Documents/Statistical%20analysis%20of%20the%20register/NMC-Statistical-analysis-of-the-register-202006-202007.pdf</ref>
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * Royal College of Midwives (RCM).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rcm.org.uk/ |title=Royal College of Midwives (RCM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151220192102/https://www.rcm.org.uk/ |archivedate=20 December 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Independent Midwives UK (IMUK).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.independentmidwives.org.uk/ |title=Independent Midwives UK (IMUK) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140925024150/http://www.independentmidwives.org.uk/ |archivedate=25 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * [[Association of Radical Midwives]] (ARM).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.midwifery.org.uk/ |title=Association of Radical Midwives (ARM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708072400/http://www.midwifery.org.uk/ |archivedate=8 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===United States=== {{Main article|Midwives in the United States}} [[File:US Navy midwife checks on a mom.jpg|thumb|US Navy midwife checks on a mother]] '''Education, training and regulation'''
There are accredited [[midwifery]] programs which lead to different professional [[midwifery]] credentials:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amcbmidwife.org/amcb-certification/why-amcb-certification-|title=Comparison of professional midwifery credentials in the U.S.|publisher=American Midwifery Certification Board (AMCB)|accessdate=2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105222335/http://www.amcbmidwife.org/amcb-certification/why-amcb-certification-|archivedate=5 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
* [[Midwifery]] programs, accredited by the Midwifery Education Accreditation Council (MEAC),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meacschools.org/|title=Midwifery Education Accreditation Council (MEAC)|accessdate=2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107004429/http://meacschools.org/|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> leading to the Certified Professional Midwife (CPM) credential,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nacpm.org/about-cpms/who-are-cpms/the-cpm-credential/|title=The CPM Credential|publisher=National Association of Certified Professional Midwives (NACPM)|accessdate=2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161223043857/http://nacpm.org/about-cpms/who-are-cpms/the-cpm-credential/|archivedate=23 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> certified by the North American Registry of Midwives (NARM),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://narm.org/ |title=North American Registry of Midwives (NARM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140430121625/http://narm.org/ |archivedate=30 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> that is at the level of a degree in midwifery (AS Midwifery, BSc Midwifery, MSc Midwifery). Completion of a Portfolio Evaluation Process (PEP) or a state licensure program are considered. CPMs have to apply for recertification every three years. * [[Midwifery]] programs (for graduates with a relevant degree who wish to become midwives), accredited by the Accreditation Commission for Midwifery Education (ACME), leading to the Certified Nurse Midwife (CNM) and Certified Midwife (CM) credentials,<ref name="CNM and CM credentials">{{cite web |url=http://www.midwife.org/The-Credential-CNM-and-CM |title=The Credentials CNM and CM |publisher=American College of Nurse-Midwives (ACNM) |accessdate=2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171110164600/http://www.midwife.org/The-Credential-CNM-and-CM |archivedate=10 November 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> certified by the American Midwifery Certification Board (AMCB),<ref name="AMCB">{{cite web |url=http://www.amcbmidwife.org/ |title=American Midwifery Certification Board (AMCB) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117063154/http://www.amcbmidwife.org/ |archivedate=17 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> that are at the level of a bachelor's degree or equivalent qualification in midwifery (BSc Midwifery). CNMs and CMs have to apply for recertification every five years.
According to each US state, a midwife must be licensed and/or authorized to practice [[midwifery]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://mana.org/about-midwives/state-by-state |title=Midwifery State-by-State Legal Status |publisher=Midwives Alliance of North America (MANA) |accessdate=21 March 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170521193338/https://mana.org/about-midwives/state-by-state |archivedate=21 May 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
'''Practice'''
Midwives work with women and their families in many settings. They generally support and encourage [[natural childbirth]] in all practice settings. Laws regarding who can practice [[midwifery]] and in what circumstances vary from state to state. Many states have [[birthing center]]s where a midwife may work individually or as a group,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.birthcenters.org/open-abc/bc-regs.php |title=Birth Center Regulations | American Association of Birth Centers |publisher=Birthcenters.org |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> which provides additional clinical opportunities for student midwives.
CPMs provide on-going care throughout pregnancy and continuous, hands-on care during labor, birth and the immediate postpartum period. They practice as autonomous health professionals working in a network of relationships with other maternity care professionals who can provide consultation and collaboration when needed. Although qualified to practice in any setting, they have particular expertise in providing care in homes and free-standing birth centers, and own or work in over half of the birth centers in the U.S. today.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nacpm.org/about-cpms/professional-standards/scope-of-practice/ |title=CMP Scope of Practice |publisher=National Association of Certified Professional Midwives (NACPM) |accessdate=21 March 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170805140052/http://nacpm.org/about-cpms/professional-standards/scope-of-practice/ |archivedate=5 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nacpm.org/about-cpms/who-are-cpms/ |title=Who are CPMs |publisher=National Association of Certified Professional Midwives (NACPM) |accessdate=21 March 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220081826/http://nacpm.org/about-cpms/who-are-cpms/ |archivedate=20 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
CNMs and CMs work in a variety of settings including private practices, hospitals, birth centers, health clinics, and home birth services. They supervise not only pregnancy, delivery and postpartum period care for women and their newborns, but also provide gynecological care for all women and have autonomy and prescriptive authority in most states. They manage women's healthcare from puberty through post-menopause.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.midwife.org/Our-Scope-of-Practice|title=Our Scope of Practice|author=|date=|website=www.midwife.org|accessdate=2 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029042700/http://midwife.org/Our-Scope-of-Practice|archivedate=29 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> With appropriate training, they can also first assist in cesarean (operative) deliveries and perform limited ultrasound examinations. It is possible for CNMs/CMs practice independently of physicians, establishing themselves as health care providers in the community of their choice.
'''Professional associations/colleges''' * Midwives Alliance of North America (MANA).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mana.org/ |title=Midwives Alliance of North America (MANA) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150928232713/http://mana.org/ |archivedate=28 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * National Association of Certified Professional Midwives (NACPM).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nacpm.org/ |title=National Association of Certified Professional Midwives (NACPM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151116044449/http://nacpm.org/ |archivedate=16 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * American College of Nurse-Midwives (ACNM).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.midwife.org/ |title=American College of Nurse-Midwives (ACNM) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511215120/http://www.midwife.org/ |archivedate=11 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Men in midwifery == [[File:Jordmor jim- oslo.jpeg|thumb|A male midwife in [[Oslo, Norway]]]]
Men rarely practice midwifery for cultural and historical reasons. In ancient Greece, midwives were required by law to have given birth themselves, which prevented men from joining their ranks. In 17th century Europe, some [[barber surgeons]], all of whom were male, specialized in births, especially births requiring the use of surgical instruments. This eventually developed into a professional split, with women serving as midwives and men becoming [[obstetricians]]. Men who work as midwives are called ''midwives'' (or ''male midwives'', if it is necessary to identify them further) or ''accoucheurs''; the term ''midhusband'' (based on a misunderstanding of the etymology of ''midwife'') is occasionally encountered, mostly as a joke. In previous centuries, they were called ''man-midwives'' in English.<ref name="Pilkenton 2008">{{Cite journal |title = Midwifery: A career for men in nursing |last = Pilkenton |first = Deanna |last2 = Schorn|first2 = Mavis N |date = February 2008 |journal = Men In Nursing}}</ref>
[[William Smellie]] is credited with innovations on the shape of [[forceps]]. This invention corresponds with the development towards obstetrics. He advised male midwives to wear dresses in order to reduce controversy over having a man present at birth.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title=Midwifery: A Career for Men in Nursing|journal=Men in Nursing Journal|volume=}}</ref>
As of the 21st century, most developed countries allow men to train as midwives. However, it remains very rare. In the United Kingdom, even after the passing of the [[Sex Discrimination Act 1975]], the [[Royal College of Midwives]] barred men from the profession until 1983.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/11202075/No-job-for-a-man-Meet-the-male-midwives.html|title=No job for a man? Meet the male midwives|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-12-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222144128/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/11202075/No-job-for-a-man-Meet-the-male-midwives.html|archivedate=22 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As of March 2016, there were between 113 and 137 registered male midwives, representing 0.6% of all practising midwives in the UK.<ref>[https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/quantity_of_midwives_registered#incoming-876626 Quantity of Midwives Registered with the NMC that are Male] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008111419/https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/quantity_of_midwives_registered |date=8 October 2016 }}, whatdotheyknow.com</ref>
In the US, there remain a small, stable or minimally declining number of male midwives with full scope training (CNMs/CMs), comprising approximately 1% of the membership of the [[American College of Nurse-Midwives]].<ref>http://www.midwife.org/ACNM/files/ccLibraryFiles/Filename/000000001720/CoreDataSurvey_2010_one-pager.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://nursing.vanderbilt.edu/msn/pdf/nmw_midwiferyformen.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-19 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170320052445/https://nursing.vanderbilt.edu/msn/pdf/nmw_midwiferyformen.pdf |archivedate=20 March 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In some Southeast Asian cultures, some or even most of the traditional midwives are men.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Rosemary |last=Gianno |title='Women are not brave enough' Semelai male midwives in the context of Southeast Asian cultures |journal=Bijdragen tot de Taal-, Land- en Volkenkunde |volume=160 |issue=1 |year=2004 |pages=31–71 |jstor=27868101 |doi=10.1163/22134379-90003734}}</ref>

'''Morrnah Nalamaku Simeona''' (May 19, 1913 – February 11, 1992) was recognized as a ''kahuna lapa{{okina}}au'' (healer) in Hawai{{okina}}i and taught her updated version of [[Hoʻoponopono|ho{{okina}}oponopono]] throughout the United States, Asia, and Europe.
==Kahuna lapa{{okina}}au== Morrnah was born May 19, 1913, in [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]], to Kimokeo and Lilia Simeona, both native Hawaiians.<ref>Dept. of Commerce, Bureau of Census, Fifteenth Census (1930)</ref> Her mother, Lilia, was one of the last recognized ''kahuna la{{okina}}au kahea'' or priest who heals with words.<ref>Rodman, Julius Scammon, ''The Kahuna Sorcerers of Hawaii, Past and Present'', p. 195 (Exposition, 1979)</ref> Morrnah was a practitioner of [[lomilomi massage]] and for 10 years owned and operated health spas at the Kahala Hilton and Royal Hawaiian hotels.<ref>''Morrnah Simeona, kahuna lapa{{okina}}au'', Honolulu Advertiser, p. C4 (Feb. 17, 1992)</ref> Among her massage clients at the Hilton spa were [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], [[Jackie Kennedy]], and [[Arnold Palmer]].<ref>Dye, Bob, ''Hawai{{okina}}i Chronicles II: Contemporary Island History from the Pages of Honolulu Magazine'', p. 298-301 (Pitzer, Pat, ''Kahuna, The Keepers of the Secrets'', Nov. 1984), University of Hawai{{okina}}i Press (1997) {{ISBN|0-8248-1984-5}}</ref> In 1983, she was recognized as a ''[[kahuna]] lapa{{okina}}au'' (healer) and honored as a "[[Living Treasure of Hawai'i]]" by the [[Honpa Hongwanji Mission of Hawai'i]].<ref>''Five persons are named as Living Treasures'', Honolulu Star Bulletin (Feb. 12, 1983)</ref>
==Ho{{okina}}oponopono== {{main|Ho'oponopono}} In 1976 she began to modify the traditional Hawaiian forgiveness and reconciliation process of ho{{okina}}oponopono to the realities of the modern day. Her version of ho{{okina}}oponopono was influenced by her Christian (Protestant and Catholic) education and her philosophical studies about India, China, and [[Edgar Cayce]]. The combination of Hawaiian traditions, praying to the Divine Creator, and connecting problems with [[Reincarnation]] and [[Karma]] resulted in a unique new problem solving process, that was self-help rather than the traditional Hawaiian group process. She had no qualms about adapting traditional concepts to contemporary applications, though she was criticized by some Hawaiian purists. "Her system uses ho{{okina}}oponopono techniques to create a working partnership among the three parts of the mind or self, which she calls by Hawaiian names, as well as by the terms subconscious, conscious, and superconscious."<ref name="Dye Bob, Pitzer Pat">Dye Bob, Pitzer Pat</ref>
She presented trainings and lectures on ho{{okina}}oponopono to the [[United Nations]],<ref>Chai, Makana Risser, ''Na Mo{{okina}}olelo Lomilomi: The Traditions of Hawaiian Massage & Healing'', p. 47, Bishop Museum Press (2005) {{ISBN|978-1-58178-046-8}}</ref> in nearly a dozen states in the U.S., and in more than 14 countries, among them Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland, France, Russia, and Japan.<ref>U.S. Senator Daniel Akaka, ''In Memory of Morrnah Nalamaku Simeona'', Congressional Record, Proceedings and Debates of the 102d Congress, Second Session, Vol. 138, No. 43 (March 25, 1992)</ref> She presented to schools of higher learning, such as the University of Hawai{{okina}}i and [[Johns Hopkins University]], to medical facilities, religious institutions and business organizations. In 1982 she organized the ''First World Symposium of Identity of Man''.<ref>Scott, Nadine W., ''Kahuna to Explore the Ancient Ways'', Honolulu Star Bulletin (July, 1982)</ref> A reporter noted: "There was something very calming and soothing about Simeona's presence and her voice, a sense of serenity about her, as she talks about teaching people how to relieve stress and attain peace of mind."<ref name="Dye Bob, Pitzer Pat"/>
To spread her ho{{okina}}oponopono process, she founded Pacifica Seminars in the 1970s and in 1980 The Foundation of ‘I’, Inc. (Freedom of the Cosmos). In 1990, she started Pacifica Seminars in Germany. Simeona wrote three textbooks ''Self-Identity through Ho{{okina}}oponopono, Basic 1'' (128 pg), ''Basic 2'' (to use after two years of practicing) and ''Basic 3'' (to use after five years). The recommended waiting times for Basic 2 and 3 was for developing deep respect for the "Divine presence." In 1990, the English original of ''Basic 1'', 8th edition, was officially translated and printed in German and French.<ref>Simeona, Morrnah, ''Selbst-Identität durch Ho{{okina}}oponopono'', 128 pg, Pacifica Seminars (1990)</ref><ref>Simeona, Morrnah, ''L'Identité de Soi-Même par Ho{{okina}}oponopono'', 128 pg, Pacifica Seminars (1990)</ref>
In late fall 1990, her last journey for lectures and seminars took her through Europe to Jerusalem. On January 16, 1991, she came back to Germany, where she lived quietly at a friend's house in Kirchheim, near [[Munich]], until her death on February 11, 1992.
== Statue of Freedom == [[File:Emancipation-Hall 1.jpg|thumb|right|''Statue of Freedom'''s plaster model cast now resides in the [[Capitol Visitor Center]]]] On March 25, 1992, U. S. Senator [[Daniel Akaka]] (D - Hawaii), eulogized Simeona in the [[Congressional Record]].<ref name="Daniel Akaka">Daniel Akaka</ref> He noted she had learned that the original plaster cast of the cast-iron Statue of Freedom, which stands on the top of the dome of the [[United States Capitol]], was being kept in storage. She raised $25,000 to refurbish and restore it, and as a result it was moved and placed on display in the Russell Senate Office Building (now in the [[Capitol Visitor Center]]) where, Akaka said, it would serve as a remembrance of Simeona.<ref name="Daniel Akaka"/>
