London, England | orig_lang = English | subject = Accident victim, paralysed from the neck down, fights for the right to die. | genre = Drama }} '''''Whose Life Is It Anyway?''''' is a play by [[Brian Clark (writer)|Brian Clark]] adapted from his 1972 [[television movie|television play]] of the same title, which starred [[Ian McShane]]. The stage version premiered in 1978 at the [[Mermaid Theatre]] in London, and subsequently opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1979. The play involves a sculptor who is paralysed. ==Plot== Set in a hospital room, the action revolves around Ken Harrison (Claire Harrison in some later productions), a [[sculptor]] by profession, who was [[paralysed]] from the neck down ([[quadriplegia]]) in a car accident and is determined to be allowed to die. Clark presents arguments both in favour of and opposing [[euthanasia]] and to what extent government should be allowed to interfere in the life of a private citizen. In portraying Ken as an intelligent man with a useless body, he leaves the audience with conflicting feelings about his desire to end his life. ==Productions== The play was televised on 12 March 1972 by [[Granada TV]]. It was directed by Richard Everitt, with the cast that featured Ian McShane (Ken), [[Suzanne Neve]] (Dr. Scott), and [[Philip Latham]] (Dr. Emerson).Clark, Brian. [https://books.google.com/books?id=6skaF0lAAY4C&pg=PR6&lpg=PR6&dq=whose+life+is+it+anyway+play+script&source=bl&ots=LdyFNhEQPT&sig=aOs8y_d9WRnNM6jn-0DQrmhRrA8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwify6atrMzJAhVG8z4KHZKJAiUQ6AEIHDAA "Details of First TV and Stage Productions, pp. x-xii"] ''Whose Life is it Anyway?'', Heinemann, 1993, {{ISBN|0435232878}} ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' opened at the [[Mermaid Theatre]], London, on 6 March 1978, before playing at the [[Savoy Theatre]] from June 1978 to October 1979. This production originally starred [[Tom Conti]] and [[Jane Asher]]. Conti transferred to New York to star in the Broadway production, which was produced by [[Emanuel Azenberg]] and directed by [[Michael Lindsay-Hogg]]. It opened at the [[Nederlander Theatre|Trafalgar Theatre]] on 17 April 1979 and ran for 223 performances and 9 previews. Conti, who was making his Broadway debut, was joined by [[Jean Marsh]] and [[Philip Bosco]]. Conti was nominated for a [[Drama Desk Award]] and won the 1979 [[Tony Award]] for Best Actor in a Play. Both the play itself and Lindsay-Hogg were nominated as well. The play, again directed by Lindsay-Hogg, was revived on Broadway at the [[Royale Theatre]], where it opened on 24 February 1980 after nine previews. A gender reversal found [[Mary Tyler Moore]] in the lead role, renamed Claire, and [[James Naughton]] as her now-male doctor. [[Josef Sommer]] completed the principal cast. The play ran for 96 performances.[http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/10212/Whose-Life-Is-It-Anyway "'Whose Life Is It Anyway?' Broadway 1980"] playbillvault.com, accessed December 8, 2015 Moore was nominated for a Drama Desk Award as Outstanding Actress in a Play and won a special 1980 Tony Award for her performance. The play was revived in London at the [[Harold Pinter Theatre]] from January to April 2005, directed by [[Peter Hall (director)|Peter Hall]] and starring [[Kim Cattrall]] as Claire.[http://www.thisistheatre.com/londonshows/whoselifeisitanyway.html "'Whose Life Is It Anyway?' London 2005"] thisistheatre.com, accessed December 8, 2015 Husband and wife [[Laurence Luckinbill]] and [[Lucie Arnaz]] starred in the national tour of the play. The two rotated playing the patient (Ken/Claire) and doctor. ==Adaptations== {{main article|Whose Life Is It Anyway? (1981 film)}} ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' was adapted from Clark's own television film of the same title directed by [[Richard Everitt (producer)|Richard Everitt]] starring [[Ian McShane]]. A film adapted by [[Reginald Rose]] and directed by [[John Badham]] was released in 1981, starring [[Richard Dreyfuss]], [[John Cassavetes]], and [[Christine Lahti]]. Author [[David Benedictus]] adapted the play into a novel, which was also released in 1981. ==Awards and nominations== ; Awards * 1978 Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Play * 1979 Selection, [[Burns Mantle]], ''The Best Plays of 1978-1979''{{cite book |title=The Best Plays of 1978-1979 |edition= |last=Guernsey Jr. (Ed.)|first=Otis L. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1979 |publisher= [[Dodd, Mead & Company]]|location= New York & Toronto|isbn=0-396-07723-4 |page= |pages=299–314 |url= |accessdate=}} ; Nominations * 1979 [[Tony Award]] for Best Play ==References== * {{cite book | last=Clark | first=Brian | title=Whose Life Is It Anyway? A Full-Length Play | edition=First | location=Chicago | publisher=Dramatic Publishing Co | year=1974 | oclc=3530311}} ==External links== * {{IBDB show|9352|Whose Life Is It Anyway?}} * {{IBDB title|3936|Whose Life Is It Anyway?}} * {{IMDb title|0275074|Whose Life Is It Anyway?|(1972)}} * {{IMDb title|0083326|Whose Life Is It Anyway?|(1981)}} {{OlivierAward Play 1976–2000}} [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:English plays]] [[Category:Euthanasia]] [[Category:Laurence Olivier Award-winning plays]] [[Category:British plays adapted into films]] [[Category:Plays based on television plays]] [[Category:West End plays]] [[Category:1978 plays]] [[fr:C'est ma vie, après tout !]] [[pl:W końcu czyje to życie?]]

'''William Wynn Westcott''' (17 December 1848 – 30 July 1925) was a [[coroner]], [[ceremonial magic]]ian, [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophist]] and [[Freemasonry|Freemason]] born in [[Leamington, Warwickshire]], [[England]].<ref>The Isiac Tablet, about the author section</ref> He was a Supreme Magus (chief) of the [[Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia|S.R.I.A]] and went on to co-found the [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn|Golden Dawn]].
== Biography ==
He was a doctor of medicine.{{fact|date=November 2015}}
In 1871 he became active in [[Freemasonry]] where he became Master of his home Lodge three years later and also the [[Quatuor Coronati Lodge|''Quatuor Coronati'']] research lodge (Master 1893–94<ref>Ars Quatuor Coronatorum Vol. 7 1895</ref>).
In 1879 he moved to Hendon. In 1880 he began studying the [[Kabbalah]] and joined [[Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia]]. In 1882 he met [[Samuel Liddell Mathers]].
=== Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia ===
{{main|Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia}}
Westcott became chief of the SRIA with the death of [[William Robert Woodman]].<ref>Regardie, page 17</ref>
=== The Golden Dawn ===
{{main|Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn}}
Wescott co-founded the [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn]] with [[Samuel Liddell MacGregor Mathers]] and [[William Robert Woodman]] in 1887, using the motto V.H. Frater [[wikt:sapere aude|Sapere Aude]].
Around this time, he was also active in the [[Theosophical Society]], where he founded in 1891 [[The Adelphi Lodge]] in London WC. {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2010}} In 1896, he abandoned public involvement with the Golden Dawn due to pressure regarding his job as a Crown Coroner, with which it was seen as an unseemly association. He continued to head the S.R.I.A. and later was involved with the Golden Dawn breakaway [[Stella Matutina]].
=== Later years ===
He retired as a coroner after 1910, emigrated to [[South Africa]] in 1918, and died in [[Durban]] in 1925.

{{Infobox serial killer | name = Yaakov Teitel | image = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1972|11|}} | birth_place = [[Florida]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = [[Life imprisonment in Israel|Life imprisonment]] | victims = | spouse = | beginyear = | endyear = | country = [[Israel]] | states = | apprehended = }} '''Yaakov Teitel''' ({{lang-he-n|יעקב טייטל}}, born November 1972) is an American-born [[Israelis|Israeli]] religious nationalist, convicted for killing two people in 2009. Teitel, who had immigrated to Israel in 2000, settling in a [[West Bank]] [[Israeli settlement|settlement]],<ref name="ynet">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3798629,00.html |title=Settler suspected of multiple hate crimes |work=[[Ynetnews]] |date= 1 November 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-02 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1125063.html |title=Settler admits to murder, series of bomb attacks |work=[[Haaretz]] |first=Amos |last=Harel |date=1 November 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-02}}</ref><ref name="time">{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1934103,00.html |title=Accused Jewish Terrorist Jack Teitel |date= 3 November 2009 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |first=Randy |last=James |accessdate=2009-11-03 }}</ref> confessed to planning and committing various acts of terrorism and hate crimes against [[Palestinians]], [[Homosexuality|homosexuals]], [[Left-wing politics|left-wingers]], missionary [[Christians]], and police officers across Israel. Teitel was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]], which he is currently serving.
== Early life == Yaakov Teitel was born in 1972 in [[Florida]], United States, and moved to [[Norfolk, Virginia]], when he was a teenager. His father, Mark, was a retired [[dentist]] who had served in the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] during the [[Vietnam War]], and his mother, Dianne, was a medical secretary - both of whom became [[Haredi Jews]] later in life. Commonly known as Jack, Teitel attended [[university]] and received a bachelor's degree in [[psychology]], and in the mid-1990s, he began making regular visits to Israel. He was arrested in August 1997 on suspicion of murdering a [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] [[shepherd]], but was released, and the case was eventually closed due to lack of evidence. Teitel subsequently returned to the United States, where he took a computer course with [[Microsoft]], and began working as a computer technician.
== Emigration to Israel == In 1999, Teitel immigrated to Israel and moved to the settlement of [[Shvut Rachel]], becoming an Israeli citizen under the [[Law of Return]] in December 2000. The following year, his parents and sister also emigrated to Israel, and settled in [[Beitar Illit]], an [[Ultra-Orthodox Jews|Ultra-Orthodox]] city in the [[Gush Etzion]] settlement bloc. In 2002, Teitel met Rivka Pepperman, a [[United Kingdom|British]]-born dance teacher originally from [[Broughton Park]], [[Manchester]], whose family had moved to Israel in 1981. They married the following year, and had four children. Teitel was summoned by [[Israel Defense Forces]] for preliminary checks, but was exempted from [[conscription]] due to his advanced age, medical history, and familial state.<ref>{{cite web|author=By Gili Cohen6 hours ago |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/who-is-suspected-jewish-terrorist-yaakov-teitel-1.4998 |title=Who Is Suspected Jewish Terrorist Yaakov Teitel? |publisher=Israel News Haaretz.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/israel-news/21868/jewish-terrorist-god-proud-me |title=Jewish 'terrorist': God is proud of me |publisher=The Jewish Chronicle Thejc.com |date=2009-11-12 |accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref>
Teitel was considered an outcast in the settlement due to his limited proficiency in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and reclusive behavior. He hardly left his home, and did not regularly participate in services at the local synagogue.<ref>https://www.haaretz.com/1.5227288</ref><ref>http://jewishweek.timesofisrael.com/the-two-faces-of-accused-terrorist-jack-teitel/</ref>
== Terrorist acts and arrest == Teitel was arrested in [[Jerusalem]]'s [[Har Nof]] neighborhood on October 7, 2009, while posting [[flyer (pamphlet)|flyer]]s praising the [[2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting]]. He attempted to throw away a bag he was carrying, but it was retrieved, and was found to contain two [[handguns]]. Teitel was then turned over to [[Shin Bet]] for interrogation, while special police units raided his home and the homes of his brother-in-law, parents, and mother-in-law. The search of his property revealed a cache of guns, parts used in [[explosive]] devices, pellets used to maximize the impact of explosives, [[binoculars]], and flyers containing [[anti-gay]] incitement. The explosives were all detonated safely by the police, and a search of his home two days later found a [[bomb]] buried in the backyard.<ref name="ynet" />
Israeli police revealed that Teitel, acting alone, confessed to a string of terrorist attacks and attempted attacks. Teitel confessed to having carried out a [[Ze'ev Sternhell#Attack|pipe-bomb attack against Ze'ev Sternhell]], as well as the murders of a Palestinian taxi driver and a [[West Bank]] shepherd in 1997, a 2006 attempted bombing near the settlement of [[Eli, Mateh Binyamin|Eli]], three bombings against police targets and a [[Christian]] monastery in 2007, and sending a [[booby-trapped]] package that injured a teenage boy to the home of a [[Messianic Judaism|Messianic Jewish]] family in [[Ariel (city)|Ariel]].<ref name="ynet"/><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The Irish Times]] |date=2 November 2009 |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2009/1102/1224257903312.html |title=Israeli police arrest West Bank settler over Palestinian killings |first=Mark |last=Weiss |accessdate=2009-11-02 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[CBN News]] |date=6 November 2009 |url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/insideisrael/2009/November/Suspect-Arrest-Announced-in-Ami-Ortiz-Case/ |title=Suspect Arrest Announced in Ami Ortiz Case |first=Chris |last=Mitchell |accessdate=2009-11-30 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=Haaretz |date=1 November 2009 |url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasen/spages/1125062.html |title=Who is suspected Jewish terrorist Yaakov Teitel? |first=Chaim |last=Levinson |accessdate=2009-11-02}}</ref> In addition to Teitel's confession, his [[DNA]] was found to match DNA retrieved from Sternhell's home after the bombing attack.<ref name="ynet"/> Teitel also confessed that he had planned to fly a remote-controlled toy plane containing explosives into the [[Tel Aviv]] gay pride parade, and that he planned a bombing against a [[Jerusalem]] gay bar. He also admitted that he planned to fire an improvised [[mortar (weapon)|mortar]] against the [[Al-Aqsa Mosque]], but abandoned the plan over fear of injuring Jewish worshippers on the [[Temple Mount]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/LandedPages/PrintArticle.aspx?id=164915 |title=Leaks are prejudicing course of justice, complains Ya'acov Teitel's new attorney |publisher=Jpost.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref>
Teitel was also suspected of murdering two police officers in the [[Jordan Valley (Middle East)|Jordan Valley]], and confessed to the [[2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting|gay centre shooting]] in Tel Aviv in 2009, though police stated that they were certain he was not involved in either.<ref name="time" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1257417385328&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |title=Police clear Yosef Espinoza, suspected Teitel accomplice |first=Ben |last=Hartman |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date= 5 November 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-06 }}</ref> Following the discoveries, Teitel was held by Shin Bet in special custody for 48 hours, without being allowed to see an [[Lawyer|attorney]] or brought before a judge. The [[Petah Tikva]] District Court denied appeals from his attorney to meet with him, and subsequently extended both his remand and the special ordnance banning him from meeting his lawyer. All of Teitel's [[arraignment]]s were held behind closed doors, and a [[gag order]] was imposed on the case.<ref name="ynet"/>
On 10 November 2009, the Jerusalem District Prosecutor's Office declared that Teitel would be charged for the murder of the two Palestinians, incitement to racism, deploying explosive devices, and sabotage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1127200.html |title=Alleged Jewish terrorist to be charged with murdering two Palestinians |first=Chaim |last=Levinson |work=Haaretz |date= 10 November 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-10 }}</ref> Teitel's legal defense was provided by ''Honenu'', an organization which provides legal defense for Israelis accused of crimes against Arabs or the Israeli security forces. Honenu founder Shmuel Meidad suggested that Teitel may be [[Insanity|mentally unstable]], stating that, "It's my impression that this man is sick, but he's not nearly as sick as the state."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1257455202910&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |title=Teitel's defense provided by 'Honenu' |first=Ben |last=Hartman |work=The Jerusalem Post |date= 7 November 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-10 }}</ref> On 4 May 2010, Jerusalem's district [[psychiatrist]] ruled Teitel unfit to stand trial. The evaluation was criticized by [[Israeli-Arab]] [[Knesset]] members, with [[Ahmad Tibi]] stating, "An Arab who shoots a Jew in Israel is a terrorist, but a Jew who shoots Arabs is insane."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/jewish-terror-suspect-unfit-to-stand-trial-1.288172 |first=Chaim |last=Levinson |title=Jewish terror suspect 'unfit to stand trial' |work=Haaretz |date=4 May 2010 |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> Following a new psychiatric evaluation, the district court overturned the previous ruling, and declared Teitel fit for trial, on 30 August.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3946310,00.html |first=Aviad |last=Glickman |title=Teitel deemed fit to stand trial |work=Ynetnews |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref>
== Conviction ==
In February 2012, the Jerusalem District Prosecutor's Office and Teitel's attorneys reached an agreement under which he would confess to two counts of murder. Teitel's attorneys confessed on his behalf, as Teitel himself announced that did not recognize the court's jurisdiction. After the indictment, the defense and prosecution would argue over whether Teitel was aware of his actions and is fit for trial, and the court would deliberate over whether Teitel is accountable for his actions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4190367,00.html |title=Ynetnews News - State reaches settlement with Jack Teitel |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref> In January 2013, Teitel was convicted on two counts of murder and two counts of attempted murder, with the court rejecting the defense's arguments that he was legally insane.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4333417,00.html |title=Ynetnews News - 'Jewish terrorist' Jack Teitel convicted |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref> In April, he was sentenced to two life sentences and 30 years for the murder of two Palestinians, the attempted murder of two others, and other offenses, and ordered to pay mandatory compensation of NIS 650,000 to the families of the victims.<ref>Chaim Levinson, [http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/jewish-terrorist-jack-tytell-gets-two-life-sentences-for-murder-of-palestinians.premium-1.514515 'Jewish terrorist Jack Tytell gets two life sentences for murder of Palestinians,'] at [[Haaretz]], 9 April 2013</ref>
